business.start.para: Mr SPEAKER(Mr Neil Andrew) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, the Minister for Defence will be absent from question time today, and questions relating to defence matters should be directed to the Assistant Minister for Defence, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and, in relation to other matters for which he takes questions in this place, questions should be directed to the Minister for Sport and Tourism.

—My question is to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Given Indonesia's imminent revocation of control over East Timor, what interim arrangements does Australia propose for the Timor Gap Zone of Cooperation to ensure that the Elang-Kakatua oilfield continues production and that the $2.1 billion Bayu-Undan liquids and gas project proceeds as planned? Are you aware of the recent statement of the Indonesian Minister for Mines and Energy that Indonesia will formally revoke the Timor Gap Treaty and, in doing so, presumably shut down the Australia-Indonesia Joint Authority for the Zone of Cooperation? Is it not also the case that the Indonesian technical director of the joint authority has declared Indonesia may well assert a continuing claim to parts of the Timor Gap? What action has the government taken to clarify Indonesia's intentions and to discourage disputation which may jeopardise the project and this substantial future revenue source for East Timor?

—First, I thank the honourable member for his question and for raising this important issue. When I first met Xanana Gusmao and some of the East Timorese way back early this year, this was, even then, one of the issues on our agenda; so I want to make it clear that the government has, over quite a long period of time, developed a strategy to achieve a smooth transition of the Timor Gap Treaty from Indonesia to East Timor—in consultation with, of course, the key state and territory governments in this country as well as with industry.

answer.para: Before 30 August, the date of the ballot, the government informally discussed the issue with key international players and not just with the East Timorese. The exact date on which I discussed the treaty with Xanana Gusmao was 25 February. We did not think it was appropriate to discuss the issue too publicly and too openly before the 30 August ballot, because obviously that would have pre-empted the outcome of the ballot and we did not want to give the public impression of any expectation of how we thought the ballot would go. Since 30 August, the government has been implementing its transition strategy, including through talks with the United Nations and the East Timorese representatives. My officials have discussed it with Jose Ramos Horta and, just last week, with Mr Mari Alkatiri, who is a senior CNRT official whom the honourable member may have met. He is also an energy expert for the CNRT and has confirmed to officials a desire to move forward on future treaty arrangements. We see this as consistent with an early and smooth transition providing a solid basis for continued long-term investment in the Timor Gap. Some adjustments will have to be made to the treaty, of course—primarily in the arrangements for the joint authority, which the honourable member referred to in his question. It is the joint authority which manages the rights and responsibilities under the treaty on a day-to-day basis.

In any case, I can report to the honourable member and to the House that we are happy with the way the discussions are proceeding. We think that the Indonesian government will be very cooperative in the process of transition. Equally, all the signs are very positive—and have been right from my meeting with Xanana Gusmao on 25 February—from the East Timorese as well. So we do not foresee any significant difficulties, but obviously there will be the sorts of transitional issues that the honourable member alluded to that will have to be concluded. I might just make one other point as well. After the MPR has passed its vote East Timor will move to be a United Nations territory and so we have been discussing this issue with the United Nations in particular because it is they who will have to administer the treaty as well in the interim period.

subdebateinfo.title: East and West Timor: Displaced Persons

talk.start.para: —My question is also addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Would the minister inform the House of the Australian government's efforts to assist internally displaced people in both East and West Timor?

—I thank the honourable member for Menzies for his question and for his interest. Members of the House will be aware that there are a very large number of displaced East Timorese in both East and West Timor. The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees estimates that somewhere between 150,000 and 230,000 displaced people are in West Timor. While it is difficult to quantify, there are reports of around 200,000 East Timorese displaced within East Timor itself.

answer.para: Today the government is announcing a $6 million package of additional assistance to displaced East Timorese people. We are very concerned about the conditions of these people—in particular, leading up to the wet season, which is about to begin. So this assistance will address some of those issues. We are providing emergency shelter materials. Family kits will be provided, which will comprise items such as plastic sheeting, timber and tools, as well as soap and water containers. There will be enough kits to provide basic shelter for around 18,000 people. We are also ready to assist those who have the capacity to begin to support their own food needs. Now is a very low point in the agricultural cycle. We will be providing 30,000 seed and tool packs through Australian non-government organisations. The government will provide funding and logistical support to help the United Nations World Food Program activities—and that includes purchasing 10 four-wheel drive trucks to allow the delivery of relief assistance to remote areas during the wet season and continued support for air and sea transport services between Darwin and East Timor which back up the ongoing relief effort.

As I said at the beginning, we are very concerned about the humanitarian situation in West Timor as well. We do welcome the recent repatriation flights from West Timor as a first step, but we continue to encourage the Indonesian government to permit voluntary repatriation. Of this package we are announcing today, $2 million will be directed to displaced people in West Timor, including funding for United Nations High Commission for Refugees repatriation programs. It will provide for basic needs of displaced persons living in camps or within host communities in West Timor until they are able to return to their homes. The task of recovery for these people will be difficult. The government calls on the international community to join with Australia in helping these people. But we are determined to provide practical and effective assistance to the East Timorese people.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Treasurer. I ask whether he has seen the recent comments of small business spokesman Rob Bastion:

question.para: We're most concerned about the proposal to tax trusts as companies. But that's not set to come in until 2001, so we have time to lobby the government to try and change that.
Treasurer, given that you have already put this measure off for a year, costing up to $900 million, will you guarantee not to water it down further?

talk.start.para: —The answer to the first part of the question is no. In relation to the second part of the question, this was the government that came up with the policy of entity taxation. We remain committed to introducing it. Needless to say, I would point out that in 13 years of government the Australian Labor Party showed not one whit of interest in this subject—not one whit of interest. As per usual, it took the coalition to deal with the legacies of Labor failure and mismanagement. The Labor Party only ever got interested when it had the capacity to do nothing. When it had the capacity to do something, it showed not one whit of interest. It got interested in this issue only once the capacity to do anything about it had completely gone from it after 13 years.
—My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Treasurer, would you inform the House of the benefits for small business, farmers and families flowing from reductions in capital gains tax?

—I thank the honourable member for Kooyong for his question. Like other members of the Liberal and National parties, he will be very interested in the benefits to small business from cutting capital gains tax. On this side of the House, where there is a deep commitment to the small business community of Australia, we make no apology for cutting Labor's capital gains tax on small business. Labor was the party that introduced capital gains tax—some of the highest capital gains taxes in the developed world—and it appears that Labor is going to fight to retain them.

answer.para: On this side of the House we have announced real provisions to help small business. The first thing we say for small business people is that when they sell their business—in which they have wrapped up all of their life, all of their savings and all of their work—only 50 per cent of the assets of that business will be taxable. That is an extension to the small business owners of this country. In addition to that, for the 50 per cent that will be taxable, the government intend to introduce a 50 per cent disregard in relation to the gain. We are waiting, of course, for the Labor Party to announce their position as they desperately search around for a policy on this issue, but it appears that, as on most occasions, because they are unable to articulate a policy, they will say, `No, no, no. Vote no, no, no,' and oppose any reform.

The small business people of Australia will be interested to know that Labor supports higher taxes on their business. The coalition wants to cut the capital gains on the small businesses and farmers of Australia. In addition to that, if they hold an asset for 15 years and they are retiring—a farmer, for example, selling the property to go into town on retirement—under the coalition proposal, which the Labor Party will not support, the sale of that asset will be capital gains tax free. And won't that be great news for the farmers of Australia! In addition to that, as a result of the government's share ownership proposals, 32 per cent of Australians directly own shares. In the sale of the first tranche of Telstra, 560,000 Australians purchased shares. I believe that in relation to that first tranche something like 75 per cent of Telstra employees took up shares. These are Telstra employees who own shares. The Labor Party wants to tax them on the gain at 48c—Telstra employees taxed at 48c on the Telstra shares they took out.

Thirty-one per cent of Australians now owning shares need to know this: the Labor Party wants to tax them at full marginal rates on the gains on those shares. The Labor Party, first having tried to prevent them taking up shares, now wants to tax them for the privilege of having taken them up—modern socialism in the hands of the Labor Party: first of all, try to prevent them getting a saving and, if they manage to slip through the net, try and tax the saving at rates of 48 per cent. On this side of the House, we have a policy to encourage share ownership. We congratulate those Telstra employees who have taken out shares and we think they deserve tax relief on their savings. This is the side of the House that wants to deliver benefits to the Telstra employees and to the millions of Australians that now have shares in Australian companies.

talk.start.para: —My question is again to the Treasurer. Treasurer, given your insistence that Ralph's findings be accepted at face value, do you accept his finding that your crackdown on the fringe benefits tax exemption for charities is flawed because, rather than save over $200 million per year, it will actually cause a significant loss to revenue? Treasurer, are you relaxed about this revenue loss or are you prepared to consider an alternative?

—As I recall the Ralph findings, he said that you should not have any exemption for charities. The government has a provision for $17,000, grossed up value, being exempt for charities. I make the point to the charities that it excludes all of the things that are not subject to FBT in the first place—it does not apply to their computers, or their laptop computers, or their briefcases or their airline memberships. All of the excluded benefits are not taken into account in relation to that $17,000. It means that charities can still give a car, completely tax-free, plus about another $1,000 of benefits. Mr Ralph said nothing. The government has a policy of a grossed up value of $17,000.
—He did actually say something.
—Mr Ralph said they should not have any exemption and that, if you wanted to help charities, you should instead send them grants. That is what Mr Ralph said.
—Oh! I see.

—The point I am making is that the government has a more generous treatment than is recommended by Ralph. From the interjections of the member for Hotham, I take it he disagrees with the governments' policy. Mr Speaker, I am giving him the opportunity to answer—
—The Treasurer knows—
—This is the first time I have ever known him to be silent in the House of Representatives: you ask him what his policy is and you stop the interjections, Mr Speaker.
—Treasurer, I have the floor. The Treasurer knows that he is not free to invite the Deputy Leader of the Opposition to respond to questions. I invite him to respond to the question he was asked.

—I assume that the Labor Party will oppose this policy, as they oppose all policies. Just before they make a formal announcement opposing the government's policy on this, and hold out to the charities their opposition to it, let me say that I went back and got the Labor Party policy in the last election. Right after the part where they promise to increase capital gains tax on pre-1985 assets, and right after the part where the member for Hotham promised to put higher taxes on four-wheel drives, because he was going to drive the Toorak tractors off the road, the Labor Party said:

answer.para: A Labor government will reform the fringe benefits tax to limit the value of FBT benefits that can be provided by certain institutions which enjoy concessional FBT treatment to $17,000 of grossed up benefit.
So he walks to the dispatch box to query his own policy. Bring back Gareth!

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker—
—The Treasurer has concluded his answer; the Deputy Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat.

subdebateinfo.title: Rural and Regional Australia: New Apprenticeships Program

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Would the minister advise the House what progress has been made with the government's new apprenticeships initiative in rural and regional Australia? Is the minister aware of any alternative approaches?

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr KEMP
talker.role: Education, Training and Youth Affairs; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —I thank the member for Longman for his question and I acknowledge his deep interest in providing young people in his electorate with good-quality training opportunities leading on to real jobs. Earlier this year, I announced the rural and regional new apprenticeships initiative, which delivered on the government's commitment to provide a much-needed boost to training and jobs in rural and regional Australia. This initiative provided an additional $1,000 payment to employers of new apprentices in occupations where there were skill shortages. I am pleased to inform the House that following this initiative there has been a boost of new apprenticeship numbers in rural and regional Australia. Between January and June of this year, there have been over 6,400 new apprenticeship registrations in occupations eligible for the rural and regional new apprenticeship incentive payment. That is a 14 per cent increase on the number of registrations over the same period in 1998. The government expects that some 30,000 new apprentices over a five-year period will benefit from this initiative.

answer.para: While the government is expanding job opportunities and quality training for young Australians, there is a deathly silence on the other side of the House. I was asked whether I was aware of alternative policies. We saw what the member for Batman put forward when he was in the shadow portfolio—not a single question or issue raised in this House during question time since the election. Of course, that is what we would expect from the member for Batman, a failed ACTU president. They still have not got over the disappointment at the failure of their attempt to wreck the apprenticeship system. The record of the member for Batman presents a challenge to the member for Dickson. She is known for her lack of portfolio activity but it is very hard to believe that she will not be tempted at some time to ask a question in this House.

Her first press release confirmed that she is going to follow in the footsteps of the member for Batman. She did not mention apprenticeships or training when she took on the portfolio. It was apparently beneath her notice. When she was interviewed on the Sunday program, she was actually quite explicit about the strategy that she intends to pursue. She said:
I think that there are some rules that seem to operate when I open my mouth.
The reporter said: `Yeah.' The member for Dickson went on to say:
I'll just have to keep my mouth closed.

So there we have a declaration of intent that there will be no policy from the member for Dickson on apprenticeships and quality training. Vocational education and training is vital to Australia's future. This Howard government has breathed new life into the apprenticeship system. We have rebuilt the apprenticeship system after Labor put the ACTU in charge and very nearly wrecked it. Now we are increasing opportunities for quality training for young people in regional and rural Australia, and on the other side of the House there is nothing but a crashing policy vacuum which reflects the lack of leadership on the part of the Leader of the Opposition.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Prime Minister. Prime Minister, given your undertaking at the 1998 Constitutional Convention that, should it fail to express a clear view on a preferred republic model, the people would be asked to vote in a plebiscite on alternatives, and given that less than half the delegates at that convention supported the parliamentary appointment model, why was no plebiscite held? Why is this unpopular model now being put to referendum at great expense? With opinion polls consistently showing that about 70 per cent of people want a directly elected President model, where will you take the republic issue if the proposed model is rejected on 6 November?

—The member for Calare will be aware of the history of this matter that: before the 1996 election I undertook that, if the coalition won, we would hold a Constitutional Convention. We delivered on that commitment. I was a participant in that convention, along with many others in this chamber. The announcement I made at the end of the convention that we would put the model that received clear support at that convention to the Australian people was greeted with widespread support, including from the leaders of the Australian Republican Movement, the Leader of the Opposition and the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate. I say with great respect to the member that any attempt now, months after that event, to pretend that at the time what I announced the government were going to do was not in accordance with the wishes of the convention is completely wrong. This is a matter on which the government parties are allowed a free vote. I do not intend to pass any comment on the merits of the arguments for or against the question because I do not believe, given the free vote stance of the government, question time is an appropriate forum to do that, but I will talk on process. I would remind the member for Calare that at every stage I and the government have been totally candid with the Australian people.
—You've been a sneak. That's what you've been.
—Order! The member for Banks is warned!

—I have never disguised my own position from the Australian people. I have never walked away from the commitment I made to have a convention. We are having a referendum on 6 November. I am not going to answer a hypothetical question. As is implicit in the fact that the government is holding a referendum, it will abide by the outcome. This is a matter for the Australian people and the Australian people alone to decide. I will accept and respect whatever decision the Australian people make, as I should.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Price Rises

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Treasurer, what action is the government taking to ensure that businesses do not profiteer in the lead-up and transition to a new tax system?

—I thank the honourable member for Macquarie for his question and for his considerable help and expertise in relation to tax matters. He has raised with me the question of the powers to monitor price increases, particularly to ensure that businesses do not use tax changes as an opportunity to increase prices. The government has amended the Trade Practices Act to prevent price exploitation in the lead-up to the new tax system with fines of up to $10 million for companies and $500,000 for individuals who try to use the tax changes to profiteer. In addition, the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission can serve a notice on a company when it believes there may be price exploitation and the company must justify its position. The ACCC has power to monitor prices generally and particular industries can be declared by the Treasurer. In those circumstances, the industries concerned have to give prior notification of price changes.

answer.para: Some members have raised with me the question of insurance companies and some of the insurance premiums that are now being charged with tax. It is fair to say that that portion of an insurance contract to be performed after 1 July 2000 is subject to GST. In relation to that part of the contract and that part of the contract only, there would be a liability. Some members have raised with me the question of whether insurers are passing this matter on properly. In response to their inquiries, I have had discussions with the Chairman of the ACCC, Professor Fels, who has already had some discussions with insurers. But I have asked him to look at some of the complaints that have been forwarded to me and to have some discussions with the insurance companies to make sure that they—who, I admit, have had some bad losses through catastrophes such as the Sydney hailstorm quite recently—do not use tax changes as a cover for recovering losses or raising premiums.

The ACCC has already written on one occasion to the Insurance Council of Australia indicating that some of the comments made on behalf of that organisation have been unhelpful and could lead to suspicion about price fixing. That letter was written back in April 1999. As a result of the representations that have been made to me, I have asked Professor Fels to have another look at the insurance industry. Professor Fels will be reporting to me. He has the full panoply of powers that the government has given to him under the Trade Practices Act and, in addition, can recommend a declaration in relation to a certain industry. So to those members who have raised this particular issue with me, I thank them very much for doing so. I can indicate to them that steps are already in train in response to those representations, and I will certainly be reporting to those members concerned the outcome of those investigations.

talk.start.para: —Before I call the member for Grayndler, I know he would want to join me in acknowledging that we have present in the gallery this afternoon the Hon. John Murray and his wife, Maureen. Mr Murray is the Speaker of the New South Wales state parliament. On behalf of all members, I welcome him and his party to the parliament.
—Hear, hear!

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Site Fees

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Community Services. Is the minister aware that there are over 160,000 Australians who live permanently in mobile homes, caravans or manufactured home parks and that as at the last census 6,649 live in his marginal electorate of Richmond? Does the minister support the GST being applied to these residents' site fees? Has the minister received any complaints from constituents in his marginal electorate following his comments in the Daily News last week that `site fees are not the same as rent' and that this is `nothing new'?

—I would like to thank the member for Grayndler, who has a keen interest in coming to the wonderful electorate of Richmond. I am not quite sure whether you are coming there for holidays. But I am fully aware of the rights of people in mobile home parks. As you correctly point out, I have many residents in my electorate who have chosen the lifestyle of living in mobile home parks, and there are many very good citizens. As they well know, prior to the last election we were very open and transparent about the GST, particularly the relationship that it had to rent and particularly the relationship that it had to mobile home parks. The facts are, and perhaps I can reiterate them for you, that as you are no doubt aware division 87 of the ANTS provides concessional treatment for long-term commercial accommodation. It allows the GST to be charged on 50 per cent of long-term accommodation prices. This extra charge will be offset by the ability of the operator to claim input tax credits for a GST paid on inputs. However, in some cases where commercial premises provide no or very little short-term accommodation, the government will provide some flexibility. Park owners, as you well know, have the option to charge it or not to charge it.
—Mr Speaker, on a point of order: I ask for the minister to table the document from which he was so copiously quoting.
—Mr Speaker, on a point of order: if the honourable member read his mail, he would have it in the mail.
—That is not a point of order, as the member for Page is well aware. I ask the minister whether he was quoting from confidential papers. The minister indicates that he was.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business. Minister, would you inform the House of recent trends in both job creation and work force participation? Would you also inform the House of the government's response to any alternative strategies to the government's plans to reduce the level of unemployment?
—I can see it coming.
—I thank the member for Dunkley for his question. The member for Dickson says she can see it coming. There are serious issues which this government is dealing with.
—You are predictable, Pete.

—When it comes to employment and unemployment, I take it as a compliment when the member for Melbourne says that we are predictable. We are constantly on this issue. We consider this a very important issue. We give it the highest priority. We have policies on this issue which we are determined to press ahead with because we know that good policies implemented means good results. We have out the latest numbers from the ABS on jobs. I am pleased to report to the House that a record number of Australians are now in jobs—a total of 8.831 million people, according to those numbers released last week. Since coming to office, the coalition has seen the creation of 526,900 jobs. The unemployment rate is now at 7.4 per cent. The last figure did blip up a bit but that was because the participation rate moved up as more people took up opportunities.
—Oh, I see.
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the minister has the call.
—Well, what you see is that 81,000 jobs created or thereabouts in the last two or three months—
—That's two-thirds—
—The Leader of the Opposition!
—which represents a very strong—
—Two-thirds!

—The chair exercises a great deal of tolerance to interjections because it is part of the nature of the parliament, but for the chair to actually nominate someone, ask for their attention and then be specifically ignored is intolerable and will be treated that way no matter what office that person holds.

—Mr Speaker, I have had interjections about how things were when Labor were in office. In the 3½ years since we have been in office, 526,000 jobs have been created. Let's be generous to them: let's compare that with Labor's last six years. In that time, only 396,000 jobs were created. In terms of jobs per month, in the time that we have been in office 12½ thousand jobs a month have been created.

—You want the figure? In your last six years in office, 5,800 jobs were created per month. That is not to say that we are satisfied with progress. We are not. More needs to be done. And the people who are standing in the way of further reforms are the very people sitting on the front bench on the other side—most of them former trade union hacks sent up here as a reward for service in the trade union movement. The shadow minister did have something to say. She put out a set of numbers. When we corrected her numbers for the numerous errors—that is a little lesson to be learnt; you want to get your facts straight—compared to February 1996, the number of unemployed males, females and young people is down and the number of long-term unemployed is down. Even on the question of regions—and I think more needs to be done in terms of regional development—the shadow minister said that there were 235 areas—
—The member for Dickson!

—Right, just to get your facts straight, it is actually 227. But the interesting comparison is that that figure was 393 when Labor left office. So, again, progress is being made. Further progress will be made if we can see the passage of reforms that will help. For example, for small business, the change to unfair dismissals would help create more jobs. If we could have a better capital gains tax regime for small business—which you cannot support; you lack the leadership to support a sensible measure—that would be good for small business, that would mean more jobs. Lastly, what we would like to see from the opposition is for them to actually have a policy on this issue. We had a promise that we would have a policy position on employment by the end of September. What do we see? A statement from the Leader of the Opposition saying, `Oh, no, I have got too many balls in the air at the moment; it will have to wait until after the referendum.' People who are unemployed are sick of waiting for you. For 3½ years you have been leader; it is about time you showed a bit of leadership, actually had a policy and were prepared to stand up for the unemployed in this country.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Charitable and Non-Profit Organisations

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Community Services. Minister, do you recall the comments made in February this year by Guides Australia Chief Commissioner, Mrs Mandy Macky, who said the GST was `a tax on six- year-olds'? Further, she went on to say that the effect of the GST would be `devastating and the rise in fees would certainly reduce our membership by many thousands'. Are these valid concerns the reason why Guides Australia was de-funded on 1 October? Minister, now that you have re-funded the National Council of Single Mothers and Their Children, as announced by Senator Newman today, will you now re-fund all the other organisations that were defunded last Friday?
—This initiative is properly that of the Office of the Status of Women—
—Were you a guide?

—Yes, I was a guide. The point of the matter is that the manner in which funding has been conducted to support women's organisations has been changed, in that there are three peak groups who are now receiving $100,000 each, as distinct from a greater number who were previously receiving $50,000 each. Those three are the National Council of Women, the YWCA and the Federation of Business and Professional Women. There is a further $200,000, because the amount of funding for women's organisations remains the same, at $500 million—

answer.para: Mr Swan interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I beg your pardon—$500,000; I added a nought. There is a further $200,000 which will be available for project funding for which groups such as the Girl Guides will no doubt be applying. The $300,000 for the three peak groups is designed to give an effective voice to those groups, so that the criticism that was previously heard that the funding was not great enough to carry out proper secretariat functions has now been met.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Community Services. Would the minister advise the House how the government is addressing social security fraud? In particular, what programs are in place to ensure that social security fraud is minimised?

—I would like to thank the member for McPherson, who does a mighty job as my neighbouring MP, for her insightful question. I would like to inform the House that later today I will be tabling the 1998-99 Centrelink compliance report. This report shows that over $232 million worth of social security payments owed to Centrelink have been identified by computer data matching programs.

answer.para: During the 1998-99 financial year, there were over 3,000 convictions for welfare fraud. Centrelink's compliance activities resulted in savings to the Australian taxpayer of $20.9 million per week. Over a quarter of a million payments were either cancelled or reduced as a result of Centrelink's compliance activities, equating to almost $280 million. These figures certainly highlight that the government's action on social security fraud is achieving results.

Although this government is committed to reducing the cost of fraud and overpayments to taxpayers, I emphasise that this government is equally committed to prevention, and prevention, as we know, is always better than cure. This government takes seriously its duty to ensure the integrity of the social security system. We have a duty not only to the Australian taxpayer but also to the vast majority of Centrelink customers, who are honest and have genuine entitlements to social security payments. Later today, I will be tabling this document.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Health and Aged Care. Minister, do you recall buying a bottle of alcoholic food essence in a Canberra supermarket nearly two weeks ago and advising the House that you had written to state and territory ministers requesting that they take action that `will mean that these products will very quickly disappear from supermarket shelves, as far as I am concerned, the sooner the better'. Are you aware that just this morning I was able to buy this bottle of alcoholic essence—right next to the ice-cream—at a Canberra supermarket? Minister, given that you have given national publicity to this serious health risk, why have you not followed through with action to remove the product from supermarket shelves as a matter of urgency?

—What a pleasant change to get at least one serious question on health from the Labor Party. As I recollect, I wrote to the ministers on that day. I cannot remove the essences; the states and territories have to.

answer.para: Mr Griffin interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The member for Bruce!
—I also spoke to the ACT Minister for Health and Community Care to tell him what I had done and to alert him to the fact. It is up to states and territories to do it.

answer.para: Mr Griffin interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The member for Bruce is defying the chair!

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Forestry and Conservation. Minister, would you inform the House how the Natural Heritage Trust is working to restore, enhance and protect the natural native environment, particularly in Townsville and Thuringowa and in electorates throughout Australia?

talker.name: Tuckey, Wilson, MP
Mr TUCKEY
talker.role: Forestry and Conservation; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —I thank the member for his question. It is interesting to note that, in my travels recently to announce various NHT grants, I announced $14 million for Tasmania. A very interesting point was just made that it was going elsewhere, but not one of the Labor members in Tasmania bothered at any time to make any representations to get that money for their constituents. When the Prime Minister first advised the Australian people of our intention to sell one-third of Telstra, he made another very significant promise, which was to use the proceeds for debt reduction—that is, the reduction of the huge fiscal debt accumulated by the previous government, and the debt contemporary Australia owed to the environment. That promised funding was initially $1 billion and now stands at $1.5 million following the Telstra 2 announcement.

answer.para: One of the largest problems facing Australia today in the environmental area, and about which you, Mr Speaker, have issued constant warnings, is dryland and the associated waterway salinity. On 3 August 1999, Dr Harris of the CSIRO publicly estimated that the cost to overcome this problem over the years was in excess of $30 billion. It is a matter of statistical fact that this is almost exactly the sum of money this government has been obliged to spend in just four budgets to pay the interest on the Beazley borrowing binge. It is only this government which, in repaying that debt, is freeing up the funding needed to address many problems, including those associated with the environment. How people on that side of the House see the environment as a joke, I would like to know.
Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Oh, yes; it is a joke to say things about the environment.
—The minister has been doing a great job at addressing his remarks through the chair, and I would invite him to continue to do so.

—Through announcements made by Senator Hill, Minister Truss, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Environment and Heritage, Dr Stone, and me, the government has recently announced funding for the third year of the Natural Heritage Trust program. Over $190 million in funding for over 2,700 projects throughout Australia has been announced so far for 1999-2000. By far the bulk of these funds will be spent in regional and rural Australia for obvious reasons.
—Largely in seats held by government members.
—Yes, like the $14 million that went to Tasmania.
—The minister will come to the question.

—Last week I was present also in the electorate of Herbert, which is very ably represented by the member who asked this question, and in the adjoining electorates of Kennedy and Leichhardt to present certificates to the local community and the people they employee who will benefit from this round of funding. In the electorate of Herbert, a single grant of $164,400 will be provided for eight projects, which includes $7,000 to protect, repair and maintain the Serpentine Lagoon Wetland and $72,000 to enhance the biodiversity, habitat and connectivity between areas of high conservation value along the riparian areas of the Ross River. In the electorate of Leichhardt, $200,200 will be provided for six projects. This grant includes $36,000 to continue the implementation of the Trinity Inlet Freshwater Creeks Revegetation Strategy and $34,300 to establish a North Queensland farm forestry development committee, which has great prospects.

answer.para: Ongoing funding of almost $400,000 was presented in Cooktown for research and the reduction of the feral pig population. We were informed while we were there that that population is estimated to be between two million and nine million animals. When you look at the insects, frogs and everything that that research has identified these animals are eating, you do not wonder why we have a reduction in those indigenous species. One pig, when captured and dissected, was found to have some 300 frogs in it.

The Natural Heritage Trust is the largest environmental rescue effort ever undertaken by an Australian government. This has been achieved through a partnership between the Commonwealth government, the states, local government and particularly community groups and individuals, who have contributed a vast effort in this regard. This is a program that gets people on the ground to identify the problems and to contribute personally with the aid of federal funding. It is certainly no joke, but it is another area of policy vacuum from those opposite.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Health and Aged Care. Minister, do you still maintain that the suspect MRI contracts were signed months before the budget? Is it not the case that many of the contracts were dated as being signed between your meeting with the radiologists on 6 May 1998 and the budget on 12 May 1998? Is it not the case that one of these contracts was even signed within six hours of the budget itself? Will you now finally table the dates on these contracts so the public can judge whether you are hiding your responsibility for this leak?

—Someone has had a bad lunch over there. I thank the honourable member for her question. I have never main tained that all contracts were signed months before the budget. I have maintained that some were. I think in the past I said that I did not know the distribution at the time. As the Health Insurance Commission said at the Senate estimates committee, to release the dates would be counterproductive to their investigation, and I intend to allow the investigation to run its full term. As for the fact that any leak came from me, I completely repudiate that. Those sorts of gutter tactics will not get you anywhere.

—My question is to the Minister for Sport and Tourism. Can the minister advise as to the recent trends in inbound tourism to Australia and what the government is doing to ensure that official forecasts of visitor arrivals are achieved?

talker.name: Kelly, Jackie, MP
Miss JACKIE KELLY
talker.role: Sport and Tourism; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games

talk.start.para: —I applaud the member's interest in tourism, which is one of the largest foreign dollar generators for this country. In August 1999 we saw a 10 per cent increase in our inbound tourism numbers from August last year. That has been a major return to growth in inbound tourism for Australia. This is showing a clear recovery from the Asian crisis. We have invested $359 million in the Australian Tourist Commission for our promotions overseas, as well as around $30 million in annual funding to our tourism operators under the Export Market Development Grants. I encourage all tourism operators to have a look at the EMDG scheme as a boost to their export potential. It is evident already that Australia is well on target to achieving 8.4 million visitors to Australia in the year 2008, which sets up this industry to have an export potential of $33 billion.

—My question is to the Minister for Health and Aged Care. Does the minister recall telling the House on 27 August that he would be `deeply concerned' if he knew someone at the meeting with the College of Radiologists had a conflict of interest? Minister, were you not aware that these doctors were all practising radiologists and that some had expanding MRI practices? If you were deeply concerned, why did you not ask everyone present to declare whether they had a conflict of interest? If you told them nothing of commercial value, why were you deeply concerned and why did you swear them to secrecy?
—I do not know how I would be expected to know the nature of the practices of everyone meeting with me. They were a group of people put up by the College of Radiologists.

answer.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The member for Melbourne is warned!
—A stupid, buffoonish statement comes from the gasbag of the Leader of the Opposition. Quite frankly, it just shows you do not know the variation in radiology. You do not understand health.

subdebateinfo.title: Rural and Regional Australia: Government Support

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Transport and Regional Services. What is the government doing to support people living and working in rural, regional and remote communities, all of which are represented in my electorate of Parkes?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. He has a real interest in helping rural and regional communities that are facing very real periods of adjustment cope with that adjustment and find new economic and job futures for the people who live in those regions. Last week, the government announced that 13 regional communities would benefit from an injection of $1.6 million for a series of programs under the government's Rural Plan program. Rural Plan is part of Agriculture—Advance Australia, which is the very substantial package that the government, in its first term, put in place of the old Rural Adjustment Scheme, which was widely seen as outmoded and inadequate.

answer.para: This very substantial Agriculture—Advance Australia package included Rural Plan, which is all about supporting grassroots efforts by communities to deal with the changing economic and industry circumstances they con front and putting in place new plans, new ways forward and new strategies for more diverse and sustainable rural industries. In short, it allows them to find ways to kick-start their local economies, particularly in those areas that have been hard hit by low commodity prices and shifts in demand, such as we have very sadly witnessed in recent years in the wool industry.

Examples under the latest round include funding of $120,000 for the Planning for the 21st Century program in Loddon shire in Victoria. In the electorate of the honourable member who asked the question, the Barwon-Darling Alliance project received $120,000 to put together a strategic plan to foster the development of primary and processing industries in that region. I share some of that region with the member, in my own electorate, and levels of unemployment are tragically high, particularly among young people and indigenous people. Everything that can be done to identify new industries and new opportunities ought to be done, and we are certainly doing what we can to help. In the electorate of the member for Hume, the Lachlan Valley Horticultural Network has been funded with $150,000 to help agricultural production gear more effectively for domestic and export performance. In the electorate of Lyons in Tasmania there is the Derwent Valley Economic Renewal program. Rural Plan is another example of the kind of program that we are putting in place—a whole range of programs and a whole range of tools are being made available to rural and regional Australia at a time of real pressure and adjustment.

talk.start.para: —My question is again to the Minister for Health and Aged Care following his non-answer to my previous question. Minister, didn't you inquire as to whether any of the radiologists that you were negotiating with had MRI practices, and didn't your departmental brief outline the commercial interests of those you were negotiating with? If you were deeply concerned about any conflict of interest, why did you not ask everyone present to declare whether or not they had such a conflict? And if you told them nothing of commercial value, why were you so deeply concerned and why did you swear them to secrecy?

—Because there had already been a three-month negotiation process with the department and this was the end of it. If anything like that was to be declared, it should have been at the beginning of the process and not at the end.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Minister, could you advise the House on what steps the government is taking to promote community recognition of the centenary of the Boer War?

talker.name: Scott, Bruce, MP
Mr BRUCE SCOTT
talker.role: Veterans' Affairs; Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —I thank the Chief Government Whip for his question. I am sure that we could have had more in the parade if we had had more horsemen in the House. Over the last three days, the people of Canberra have witnessed members of the Imperial Bushmen's Contingent from all the eastern mainland states coming here to commemorate the commencement of the Boer War 100 years ago. The Boer War is a significant part of our nation's history. Some 16,000 young Australians went off to the Boer War and we lost over 600 young Australians. The three-day activity in Canberra has been appropriate because the contingent has brought alive a significant part of our nation's heritage and history. I think it was Paterson and Henry Lawson who really epitomised the bushman. Paterson was a wartime correspondent in the Boer War and he wrote about the bushmen in South Africa as hard riding and straight shooting, and larrikins to boot.

answer.para: The member for Ballarat also has some hard riding larrikins who have ridden 800 kilometres from Creswick in his electorate, just north of Ballarat, right here to Canberra to participate in this very important commemoration. One of the most interesting things about that is that they were four young people: two 17-year-olds, a 14-year-old and a 15-year-old. I think that augers well for the future of the heritage of our nation. I think those four young people—Laura and Dane Woodward, Hannah Aumann and Mark Hansen—deserve to be congratulated by members of this House. I hope that members on the other side of the House might join in congratulating those four young people, who spent 23 days riding here to Canberra so that they might have some understanding of what those who served our country might have gone through. Many of those people who did go through that experience were not much older than those four young Australians, who have ridden 800 kilometres from Victoria here to Parliament House.

The other thing that I might add, if I could, is that last night I had the opportunity to launch an Internet site through the Heraldry and Genealogical Society of Canberra. That Internet site is of Australian casualties in South Africa. In the past, these records have been held by South Africa, and we thank the South African official for making them available to us. They are an invaluable record on the Internet for all to search, and I think that also adds some significance to the occasion of the last three days. I do not think there is anything more significant, more Australian, than the slouch hat and the emu plumes that go with it, and seeing them on the young people riding up to Parliament House and the Australian War Memorial as part of the Imperial Bushmen's Contingent means that the spirit of the bushmen and the Anzac legend are alive and well in Australia, and that they will be into the century. I thank the Chief Government Whip for his question.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

—I present the Auditor-General's audit reports Nos 13 and 14 of 1999-2000: No. 13 entitled Performance audit—Management of major equipment acquisition projects—Department of Defence and No. 14 entitled Performance audit—Commonwealth debt management .

interjection.para: Ordered that the reports be printed.

talk.start.para: —Papers are tabled as listed in the schedule circulated to honourable members. Details of the papers will be recorded in the Votes and Proceedings .

speech.para: Motion (by Mr Reith) proposed:
That the House take note of the following paper:
National Museum of Australia—Annual Report 1998-99
Debate (on motion by Mr McMullan) adjourned.

talk.start.para: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Lilley proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

interjection.para: The suppression of community opinion by the government in relation to its unfair taxation and social policy agenda.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

para.inline: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

talk.start.para: —When it comes to community organisations, the government believes in social suppression and social coercion; it does not believe in a social coalition. The social coalition is the smiley mask that it puts up to pretend that it cares, to pretend that it is part of the community and has some real concern. But what we have seen from the government over the last four years have been dramatic cuts to community organisations which represent people. Last Friday we had cuts to 10 organisations: $50,000 taken away from the Guides; $50,000 from the National Council of Single Mothers and Their Children; $50,000 from the Older Women's Network; $50,000 from the Women's Electoral Lobby; $25,000 from the Catholic Women's League—and so on. But it is not just those 10 organisations that have been affected. During the period of this government, 30 organisations in all have lost over $12 million.

speech.para: Then we had the farce that occurred in the House yesterday and today. This minister is an accident looking for somewhere to go. Yesterday in this House there was an accident; he did not quite know who had been cut or why they had been cut but he embarrassed the government by saying that the Lone Fathers Association had been funded but that he was unaware of all the other organisations having been cut. In particular, one organisation that was cut was the National Council for Single Mothers and Their Children. What organisation and what group of people in this community have been singled out for special treatment from this government over the last month? Single mums and their children. Leaks from the government are that they are going to have their moneys taken away from them for their children aged 12 to 16.

We did not get any participation from the minister today; he was not game to answer the question. Do you want to know why? Because we would have had another accident. If we had had another accident, he would have been back in the House tomorrow, or Mrs Bishop would have been back in the House tomorrow, announcing the refunding of all the other organisations. So I say to him: if we come into this House every day and ask you a question about Guides Australia or the Women's Electoral Lobby, will they get funded the next day through your having been embarrassed?

You will be embarrassed because these organisations out there represent some of the most vulnerable people in the community and they cannot afford to have the funding cuts that you have imposed upon them. We have to ask ourselves why. Why have these funding cuts been imposed? Because every one of these organisations has one thing in common: every one of these organisations has opposed the government on the GST. Every one of these organisations has got up and said, `It's going to take money away from us, it's going to make it harder for families, it's going to make it a lot harder to operate. We're going to have less money to provide services to the people whom we serve.'

Over the last 12 months, the writing has been on the wall for these community organisations because, when they went before that Senate inquiry, they signed their death warrant. Make no mistake about it. When these organisations went before the Senate inquiry, thinking that we had an open and democratic practice in this country and that there would not be any thuggery or retribution from this government, they signed their funding death warrant. That is why 30 organisations in this country have been defunded—and that is particularly why the Girl Guides have been defunded.
I would like to quote from what Guides Australia had the temerity to say and be defunded for. It said:

The effect of the GST on organisations like ours will be devastating and the rise in fees would certainly reduce our membership by many thousands. To add further insult, we have been advised that the Government's current plan is to tax our young people if they themselves receive a benefit from providing services in the community, such as mowing lawns for the elderly and the disabled, visiting sick children in hospitals, washing cars for fundraising and toy-making. These services will also be GST applicable.

But to make matters worse, Guides Australia went on television and said these things. It actually articulated these concerns. When it was attacked by the thugs opposite, it did not take it—it stood up—and wrote to the paper saying:

Under the GST these volunteers become tax agents for the Government. When children bring in their weekly contribution of a few dollars, the leaders will need to put on their accountant's hat and skim off 10 per cent for the government.

That is what the Guides did. It stood up for voluntarism in the community. It stood up for community service. It stood up and it was knocked down. It stood up and it was thugged by this government. It stood up and it was silenced. Fortunately, many community organisations will not be silenced by this sort of thuggery.

Let us have a look at some of the other organisations that have been defunded. I will go through them because there were only 10 on Friday. For a government that says it believes in family values, it previously defunded Family Planning Australia, the Australian Pensioners and Superannuants Federation, the Australian Community Health Association, the Australian Catholic Social Welfare Commission and the Association of Civilian War Widows. All these organisations have one thing in common. What did they do? They criticised the government's unfair tax system. Is it any wonder that people say this government is strong in taxing and controlling the weak and very weak in taxing the strong?

Why has all this emerged this week? What is going on at the moment? Why does the government want to send a really clear message to all the community organisations that they should not stand up and oppose this government's unfair taxation agenda? What could possibly be happening at the moment that it would want to send a really tough message to all of the community organisations that they should not be speaking out against this government's agenda? What could it be? It could have nothing to do with the business tax package. I am sure it has absolutely nothing to do with the business tax package, has it? Nothing to do with the fact that the government wants to give the big end of town a huge lift and increase tax on the battlers.

By the way, we do not hear language about the battlers from this government any more, do we? Does anyone ever hear the government talking about the battlers any more? Now that you have a GST and now you believe in the principle that the less you earn the more tax you pay, do we hear anything about battlers? Now that you believe in taking the floor out of the industrial relations system and letting wages drop, do we hear anything about battlers? Do we hear anything about battlers when you articulate the principle—as you have over the past month—that if you take the wage system down then you have to take the social security system down with it?

No wonder all your ministerial journalistic staff were out there briefing the gallery over the last month that you were going to engage in the third great reform. We have the unfair GST, the second wave of industrial relations, taxes up, wages down and welfare benefits have to follow. We cannot pay those single mums too much for their children aged between 12 and 16, the malingerers might not want to work. That is what you were saying out there. So much for family values. Some parents might want to spend some time with their adolescent children just in the interests of a cohesive society. Of course, we were told who were the shirkers and who else was bludging on the welfare system. We heard all about it. It was the DSP pensioners who were all bludging on the system. Something had to be done about them.

We were treated to this parade of sneering from the sneer doctors opposite, who were saying, `If you feel insecure in your job and worried about your wages, it is not the fault of anyone above you, it is all those bludgers below you, so take out your frustration on them. Take it out on sole parents. Take it out on disability support pensioners and take it out on the unemployed.' I do not think the minister is a nasty person, but there is one sneer doctor in this House who has gone out there and reflected on the unemployed continuously, and that is the minister for employment. The minister for employment has been going around the country talking about the unemployed being job snobs and about the needy to be given a bit of tough love. Do you know where tough love is used in the United States? It is used in dog obedience training programs. That is where the term comes from. The minister went to Brisbane and there was a big feature article in the Courier-Mail. The central theme was: let's administer some tough love to those undeserving unemployed because they are all shirkers.

The reason the government has been engaged in this campaign to undermine the whole credibility of the social security safety net is that it has a blow-out in welfare expenditure. The reason it has a blow-out in welfare expenditure has nothing to do with people being bludgers and everything to do with the government's negligence and its blinkered view of the world. There are two reasons why we have a blow-out in the social security budget and the first one relates to the government's abolition of training programs, the sorts of programs that can give people the capacity to move from welfare to work, the sorts of programs like the MIFS program which they sneered at in this House some weeks ago. It is a highly successful program giving people the capacity to move off DSP. What happened to it? It was abolished, gone, just like the funding for the labour market programs and the funding for all of the 30 community organisations that funding has been taken away from. That is why there is a blow-out in the welfare system. That is the first reason.

What is the second reason there is a blow-out in the welfare dollar? Why is the welfare bill going to increase from $45 billion to $50 billion plus? Why is it going to go up by approximately $5.5 billion in a year? It is because the government has also put inadequate GST compensation into the welfare system. It spent approximately $21 billion trying to implement this unfair tax and then it wants to turn around and blame that on the recipients. It wants to blame them for the fact that it has completely stuffed up the financial bottom line and ripped away all of those programs that give people the capacity to be independent and move from dependence to independence. Then it wants to turn around and blame the victim. It is a tired, old strategy and one you have all been practising. I hope the minister does not get into the habit of it. Minister Abbott has and, of course, Minister Bishop is into a bit of it as well. But the person who has been into it most in recent times is of course Senator Newman, the welfare cut woman, the one who has all the plans bulging out of that bottom drawer.

talk.start.para: —Three-pension Jocey.

—That is right, three-pension Jocey. All those plans locked in the bottom drawer; the plans to target the people on DSP and attack those people on sole pensions. Of course, who is backing all this up? The Prime Minister. This Prime Minister has the courage of his prejudices, and his prejudices come through time and time again and they never change. I was talking to someone this morning who told me that when the Prime Minister first stood for parliament in 1974 he spoke so badly at a WEL function in Bennelong at a candidates' forum that he was rated last by the WEL group doing the judging there. He angrily stormed out of the meeting without talking to the members. He has got his own back this week. WEL has been defunded, along with all of those organisations that have had the courage to challenge the prejudices of this Prime Minister and this government.

speech.para: But it is not just those organisations. What has the government got against religion? You say you are family friendly and you believe in family values, but you go along and you defund a whole host of organisations. You have taken money away from Catholic, Jewish and Muslim women in these cuts.

talk.start.para: —Who's left?

—Is there anyone left in the community whom you do not like and want to pick on? This government has an agenda to cut welfare, because it is engaged in a massive redistribution of resources from the bottom to the top. What you are really on about here is increasing taxes on the boys and girls—such as the Guides, the Scouts, the canteens and the Brownies—and giving it all to the big boys. That is exactly what it is about. Anyone who has the temerity to stand up and say, `That is your strategy, that is what you have been up to,' anyone who takes the invitation of the parliament to appear before a Senate committee and articulate their concerns about what is happening in their society, gets defunded.

speech.para: If you speak up, you get knocked down. If you speak up under this government, you get clubbed down. So let us not hear anything about this government being compassionate conservatives. We all know that the term `compassionate conservatives' is a contradiction. It is an oxymoron. It is not possible. But we get it from this government, because they read all of the US campaign literature. Because Bush says he is a compassionate conservative and because we are introducing a harsh social agenda of a GST, they will go around and try to prove that they are compassionate.

The government will pretend to be compassionate. They will erect this smiley mask which they call `the social coalition', but what they will do all the time, underneath it all, is cut it away. The social coalition is supposed to include government, business and the community sector. It is supposed to be a three-legged stool. The problem is that they have cut off a leg. The community sector has nothing left. They have defunded it. It is going to be hit with the GST—huge impacts in terms of fringe benefits; huge impacts in terms of the administration of the GST—and all of its resources taken away, and guess what happens? The social coalition just falls over. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —After hearing that diatribe from the member for Lilley, I would like to acknowledge that I think he probably has a social conscience, but it is very misguided—as, indeed, a lot of the members in the Labor Party are. His whole premise is that we are trying to hide, that we are not being transparent. How much more transparent and open can you be than going to a general election about reforming the taxation system, a component of which was the GST? I know full well, because I ran in 1993 on similar policies—admittedly, they were changed and I paid the price—that we ran on an open and transparent new tax system. Indeed, if the new tax system is profitable for people and families, then hopefully it will start to help those people who are really in need of help to get a leg up.

speech.para: But the argument that the member for Lilley is running here today is that we are being subversive, that we are not allowing interest groups to speak. I would like to just quote Michael Raper, the President of ACOSS, who is not known as the most enthusiastic supporter of the coalition. On transparency and openness regarding their policies, he said:
We always give them a copy of a press release ahead of time and it hasn't stopped us from being very critical of the Government.

Indeed, we continue to fund a range of organisations. But the important point—and, indeed, this is what Jocelyn Newman and the government will be doing over the next few months into next year—is to have an open and transparent debate on the welfare system. And why shouldn't we? Because that is exactly the debate that the Labor Party has been having for the last nine months, whether from the member for Werriwa, the member for Lilley, the member for Grayndler or the member for Dickson—who does not quite know what portfolio she is involved with.

This debate has been open and raging for quite some time. But we want to make it controlled and to have the rest of the community and other interest groups participate. That is precisely why we are having a green paper and that is why, as was announced recently in a very good speech given by Jocelyn Newman to the National Press Club, we do wish to engage the community to ensure that people who are dependent on welfare—whether they are on unemployment benefits or disability support pensions—and those who are less disadvantaged are all encouraged to reach their maximum potential.

Many of the schemes introduced by the previous Labor government, particularly when it came to labour market organisations, did not reach the target. They did not actually help the people that they were designed to help. They were rechurning many people through labour market programs for jobs that did not exist.

Let us go to some of the points that the member for Lilley has raised. One of the issues that he talks about is the government's commitment to the funding of women's organisations. I should add, as I did yesterday, that these come under the Office of the Status of Women. I am pleased to announce that the government has announced funding for three key bodies which are well supported to represent the interests of women to the government—that is, the YWCA, the National Council of Women of Australia and the Australian Federation of Business and Professional Women. Funding to these organisations has actually been doubled to $100,000 a year. They do not always agree with the government.

Indeed, I would like to remind members opposite that this process is vigorous. We have a review of national women's non-government organisation programs, which is in consultation with women in other NGOs. We do not have a policy to defund women's organisations, as is the line being run by the member for Lilley and by the opposition. We have maintained a minimum of $500,000 annually. Indeed, the government will shortly be announcing another round when we will be giving up to $25,000 to different women's organisations.

I might add that the Howard-Anderson government has contributed significantly to delivering benefits to Australian women, and where better than in job creation. The unemployment rate at its peak in the early nineties was 11.2 per cent. That is down to just over seven per cent now. What better participation can you give both men and women than to give them a job and a future, so that they do not have to be dependent on welfare for the rest of their lives and, indeed, so that they can give a future to their children?

With regard to the National Council of Single Mothers and Their Children, I would like to announce that we have actually funded them for $100,000 over the next two years. As I mentioned yesterday, whether it be from the Lone Fathers or the National Council of Single Mothers and Their Children or other organisations, we do believe in having an equitable input from both genders and all organisations.

One of the points that I want to come to is that the member for Lilley and, indeed, many of the tactics of the opposition are very much into pointscoring and false accusations, particularly in regard to one of our major agencies, Centrelink. Centrelink provides services to over seven million Australians. It is a very large agency, taking up over one-third of the Commonwealth budget. But, of course, we never hear a good point from the member for Lilley or from the opposition. No; it is always trying to drag down one of the greatest agencies that we created through the merger of the old DSS and DEETYA. What the new Centrelink is providing is first-class service to over seven million Australians, whether they be on pensions, Newstart Allowance, Youth Allowance or any other government funding programs. So I think it is rather reckless that the member for Lilley and the opposition are more interested in promotion; recklessness and not actually telling the true story of what is happening. We are having this debate and—
Mr Swan interjecting—

talk.start.para: —the Labor Party is also having this debate. As I mentioned before, it is no wonder that the member for Lilley is looking for self-promotion and publicity on whatever particular issue or angle he can find, because there is confusion out in the media about who actually is the shadow minister for community services. One could say it could be the member for Werriwa—who has always been very articulate and is, of course, paying the price by being on the back bench now—or it could be others. But I do note that there have been some recent articles, and that reputable paper, the Daily Telegraph —which we all read religiously—says:

speech.para: First came Dolly the sheep. Now comes Wayne Smith, the first genetically engineered member of the Federal opposition shadow cabinet.

talk.start.para: —There is a photo to prove it.

—I look forward to seeing it—and we have a living photo right here—because there is confusion. Is it Stephen Smith? Is it Wayne Swan? Is it the member for Lilley? Is it the member for Dickson? Who knows? But of course it is our own GMO, our own `Wayne Smith', who we know is actually Wayne Swan, the member for Lilley. Perhaps that explains why he is spending so much time on whatever issue he can find and ducking out of here to issue press releases, whether on Centrelink or on women's issues.

speech.para: I would like to point out that today we have announced that there are six principles particularly reflecting our concern to ensure that the welfare system that we have for the next century can best achieve results and improve the viability of those people achieving their maximum potential so that they are not continually dependent on welfare. What better notion can a government or any community aspire to? The six principles that we will have for the terms of reference for the green paper that will be produced are: maintaining equity, simplicity and transparency; establishing better incentives for people receiving social security payments; creating greater opportunities; expecting people on income support to help themselves and to contribute to society through increased social and economic participation within a framework of mutual obligation. And what is wrong with that? That is the debate that you are having. The terms of reference will also include providing choice and support for individuals and families—because we are about providing choice and not just leaving people being unable to improve their potential because they are trapped in welfare dependency.

You talk about the increase in DSP. Well, the disability support pension increased more under your government than it has now we are here. What we want to ensure is that people who are on disability pensions can reach their maximum potential and maybe integrate back into the community and not feel alienated, and that we give them the opportunity. That is exactly what we intend to do, and we hope to engage the rest of the community as part of this, because it should be an open and transparent debate and not be the exclusive domain of the Labor Party, who failed so many Australians because, under them, we saw record unemployment. You failed so many Australians because, when we came into government, we had to go back and clean up a lot of the financial mess that you left that did not give opportunities to young Australians or, indeed, older Australians—the vast majority who lost their jobs through the recession that we had to have.

I would like to highlight that this is typical scaremongering that is happening from the opposition. They want to lock people into welfare dependency, and we do not. We do not want to lock them into welfare dependency, and that is why we want to try to help them, whether they are on parenting payments or disability support, or whether they are unemployed and on Newstart arrangements. That is why the Job Network, for one, has been very successful—with the cooperation of Centrelink.

As I said, when you look at DSP—and the member for Lilley uses this as his argument—it has, I admit, risen by 80,000 since 1996, but there was a 92,000 increase in the last three years of Labor. Unemployment now is just over seven per cent. Even when we came into government it was 8.5 per cent. What better thing can you give an individual or a family than to give one member—or, hopefully, a couple of members—of that family the opportunity to get full-time employment? There are a number of measures that we have taken to ensure that people who are on welfare or who need help are given that assistance. Indeed, we have provided that through the Work for the Dole scheme, through Job Network and through changes to Youth Allowance.

Youth Allowance was not a cost-cutting measure. Youth Allowance has actually cost the government more. The reason for that is that we believe that we should intervene to ensure that young Australians are given training and given a skill, and not just given a cheque—which was the case under the Labor Party, when it was easier to go on the dole than it was to get into a job or to go on to further education. That is not a cost-cutting measure: we have actually spent money there.

Our return to work program provides $24 million to assist women who want to get jobs after raising children. Work for the Dole, which I have mentioned, gives unemployed people the chance to gain work experience to improve their self-esteem and communication skills and to build motivation. It also provides an opportunity for them to make a contribution to the community. We do believe that the community has a vital role to play, and that is precisely why Jocelyn Newman and the government are having a green paper and an open discussion on welfare. Why shouldn't we be? We have tackled the hard decisions with this country with tax reform and with industrial relations reform, and we do not step away from that. Indeed, what it has achieved is a more prosperous Australia, and a more prosperous Australia means more opportunities for people who are less able to look after themselves.

The government is concerned to prevent long-term welfare dependency by helping parents on income support to plan for their future, to return to work. What is wrong with that? What is wrong with the government taking up a policy of engaging the rest of the community—whatever their gender, whatever their social standing, to ensure that when we move into the next century we have a relevant welfare system that will deliver and not trap people into a permanent dependency on welfare?
