The member for Lilley mentioned the other day that he found the speech of the Minister for Family and Community Services at the National Press Club rather lucid—and perhaps he learnt something from that. Let us hope he does learn, because he is a slow learner—we know that. That is why the press gallery still do not know who actually is the shadow minister for community services. But we know he is ably assisted by other members here.

I would like to point out that particularly low income earners, particularly people on pensions, will be compensated and compensated substantially when the new tax system comes into place on 1 July next year. It is a new tax system by which 80 per cent of Australians will pay 30 per cent less PAYE income tax. What is wrong with that? It is a tax system from which pensioners will have a four per cent increase in the rate of social security payment. And if we are wrong and inflation does move up—which we do not anticipate—by two, 2½ or three per cent, we have put in a buffer of at least two per cent to ensure that people on pensions or people on some sort of social security payment are compensated. And why should we not compensate them? We recognise that we should and we do not step away from it, because we do want to look after those people. By the same token we want to help wealth creation, we want to help families get ahead—and doing that provides not just a healthier community but a healthier place for investment. Part of that is the next thing we have done with the Ralph review. You should be endorsing that, because that will create wealth and create opportunities.

So why is it unfair that we will be having this debate? What is unfair is that you feel marginalised. You are more interested in publicity and self-promotion than you are in good policy. That is the tragedy. What we are getting from the opposition is the one-liners every day to grab the headlines—and, as I mentioned before and I will mention a third time—it is a desperate attempt to remain relevant. We are committed to all organisations. As I mentioned before, we have just announced $100,000 for the National Council of Single Mothers and Their Children. We have done the same with many other organisations. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Now, we all know how the Prime Minister tries to praise women in sport. And we all remember when the Prime Minister wrote to Australia's netball team captain—and what a wonderful captain—Vicki Wilson, to congratulate her on our international women's `hockey' team. He did the same thing a while before that by calling the Hockeyroos the Australian women's cricket team. It is embarrassing. But it shows how little this government knows or cares about women. It also draws into focus what it thinks of those organisations serving the interests of women—the non-government organisations or the government's own Office of the Status of Women.

speech.para: The Office of the Status of Women has lost its head. It was highly political in any case. It was more about conservative connections than about women's policy. It was then that the OSW lost its head because Pru Goward was not a policy person. She presided over an office which saw its budget cut in half. She was appointed to wear the flak over a major downgrading of women's issues. It was nothing more than a PR front job which easily translates to the Olympics publicity work she is going to. We can see a snow job. We can see through the shallow motives of this government when it comes to pushing its own devious, narrow little agenda.

As the member for Lilley rightly says, it is thuggery. The social coalition this government talks about is very selective. Kennett was not very conservative in putting the boot into anything which did not suit him, but this government is truly conservative in going through the charade, the performance of a sly and stealthy reshaping of the social landscape back to the desert. This government does not care about the battlers of Australia. We do not hear anything about the battlers any more, do we, Minister? This government does not know netball from hockey. The minister yesterday did not know what we were talking about. He did not answer the question. He was not on top of it, because he does not rate it as important. Anyone, any group, who does not agree does not rate. It is that simple.

The issue of assistance to non-government organisations is not about redressing any imbalances, it is not about providing incentives for social good, for community betterment. It is a welfare thing, isn't it? Conservatives have this in-built view that policy comes out of the end of a factory chimney. They also have the dangerous notion that government is paternal—that government intervention warrants gratitude, even servility. It is close to a totalitarian view. It does not make for good public policy.

It is the role of government to undertake some social evening out, to implement measures to discourage those ills which are not in the interests of the community as a whole. At the same time, governments have to guarantee the freedoms our citizens hold so dear—such as being able to criticise the government. That is not the case with this government.

The non-government groups which have had funding withdrawn have been critical. They have not served their patron. They have been made to pay. It is a form of censorship. It is not right or proper. The government says it is in search of the `moderate' voice, that the silent majority must be paid heed to, that many women's organisations do not represent the interests of all women. We can agree with that. We can agree that every view must be entertained. But when the government defunds organisations like the Women's Electoral Lobby, it is consigning it to the far off margin. When it takes funding away from the Australian Youth Policy and Action Coalition, it is silencing a policy conduit into what many of us think is one of the most important constituencies—young people. You might not agree with what they have to say, but it is critically important that you listen to them because one day they will be in charge. We all remember that Treasurer Peter Costello was once a riotous Labor orientated student with long hair. Look where he is today.

It is remarkable that, when the Howard government are criticised for its lack of women's policy—and they are about to dilute the equal opportunity legislation—when any criticism is levelled, they point to broader achievements. `Australian women are enjoying the fruits of good government,' says Minister Newman. She points to home loans, to the family tax initiative and to jobs. She might as well be pointing at more comfortable family cars, more gentle washing powders or the widespread use of the steam and dry iron! It is all part of progress. It is not real policy. It is the consequence of other policy borrowed to explain something else.

Minister Newman talks of funding that focuses on achieving real outcomes for all women, but we know that that is doublespeak: it is the women's round table—delayed, postponed, abbreviated, curtailed and muzzled to a measly 20 minutes for each of the guests, significantly reduced in number, of the government. Why do they bother at all? Because some conservative people also believe governments should deliver policies for women, and because the Howard government do not want to spook the horses—they want to slide out of the issue inconspicuously.

They have changed the rules on funding women's NGOs to bring them into line with other community groups. The Office of the Status of Women, then, is even more irrelevant. Groups seeking support have to put in a tender. It is the Job Network, isn't it? But it is more than that. The tender document calls for `constructive working relationships with the minister's office' as well as `timely advice on likely media activities'. To us, that definitely sounds very dangerous. It sounds to us like a very bad way to get policy advice. It sounds to us like that is the way to get the sort of advice the government want to hear.
Last year's budget statements authored by this government clearly state:

The purpose of this grants program is to assist women to effectively convey their views and concerns to the Commonwealth Government by providing block funding for core operational support to a limited number of representative women's non-government organisations.
And further:
Payments will be made to approximately 10 organisations following a yearly competitive selection process.

Ten organisations. Like the Office of the Status of Women, it has been halved. We are now down to three, and the announcement today that the National Council of Single Mothers and Their Children makes it four. We on this side can count; we know that that is less than half. Why chop off the Girl Guides? Why chop off the Women's Electoral Lobby? Why fund the Lone Fathers Association as a new group? Why, in this year of the older person, did the government shunt the Older Women's Network? It was the wrong constituency, wasn't it? It did not match the government's views.

If this government truly believes the pendulum has swung too far then it should face the issue honestly instead of trying to disappear those groups in the night like an extremist, right wing dictatorship. To muzzle your critics and to channel your own propaganda into those organisations under your own patronage reeks of the sorts of politics that we do not want in this open and free country where we like to debate issues, where we kick the ball around and live with our differences. That is football; it is not netball. But if, like the government, you do not care to listen to the debate, if, like the minister, you do not care, why play the ball at all?

talk.start.para: —As I was listening to the honourable member for Lilley bring on this matter of public importance today, I was reminded of that statement of Richard Ingrams, the former editor of the satirical magazine Private Eye , which I use with apologies to Mr Ingrams and with some adaptation, namely: when the honourable member for Lilley starts to speak, most normal people think of something else. This debate illustrates that precisely, particularly in the choice of matter. What we have had this afternoon is half an hour of confected indignation from the opposition, and the continuation of the scaremongering for which the member for Lilley is becoming extremely well known.

speech.para: What is the essence of the complaint that has been raised as one of such public importance here this afternoon? The essence is that certain organisations that have been funded under programs by governments are no longer funded and that some other organisations are funded. The member for Lilley has not pointed to any precise details or particulars as to whether that process of funding was inappropriate or appropriate, in some circumstances, or whether the funding that has been provided to organisations is in some way inappropriate in the circumstances. When you look at what has happened under this program, you can see a couple of things which are facts rather than simply the opinion which has been spouted forth by the member for Lilley this afternoon.

The first thing is that the amount of money provided under this program is the same as was provided before. The second thing is that there has been an open and accountable tender system—advertisements in newspapers and the like—and a selection criterion. That has been processed through in order to arrive at a situation where, after review, the representation of the interests of women in Australia is most adequately brought to the government and is most adequately done by appropriate organisations. As a consequence of that open process of tendering, an open process based on a criterion for funding in these areas, three major women's organisations have been funded to an extent far beyond that to which organisations have been funded in the past.

In fact, each of the three organisations—namely, the National Council of Women of Australia, the YWCA and the Australian Federation of Business and Professional Women—will receive $275,000 from 1 October this year until 30 June 2002 under these grants. This is the first time that organisations such as these have received grants beyond a period of 12 months. This is the first time that organisations such as these have been given grants which enable them to plan on the basis of what they can do, not just over a 12-month period but over a three-year period, to represent not only one sectional interest of women's issues in Australia but women's interests broadly right across Australia.

I ask the members of this House and the people who are present here today and listening to these proceedings: what can be fairer than that? What can be fairer than to provide an open system of tender whereby all organisations are entitled to put forward what they believe is the appropriate way to represent women in Australia, that that be judged according to criteria and that the recipients of these funds get double the amount previously provided over a period three times longer than previously provided? What can be fairer than that? But, as usual, all we get from the opposition is the whingeing which we have heard this afternoon.

talk.start.para: —There's no diversity, mate.

—Is the honourable member saying in this debate this afternoon that the National Council of Women of Australia do not represent a diverse range of women within this country? Is the honourable member saying—and I am listening for his next interjection—that the YWCA does not represent a diverse range of women's interests in Australia? Is he saying that the Australian Federation of Business and Professional Women do not equally represent a wide range of interests in Australia?
—There's not enough diversity. Listen to what I said.
—You said there was none before, but now there is not enough diversity!
—The member for Menzies will ignore the interjections of the member for Braddon, who will keep quiet.

—I apologise, Mr Deputy Speaker. I was tempted beyond what I should have been. The reality is that these are three well-established, well-known, well-regarded and highly credited organisations that represent a wide cross-section of women in Australia. As well, the criteria by which they were selected in order to receive these grants ensured that they do not simply represent any one sectional interest of Australian women.

speech.para: Over and above the additional funding to these organisations, a further $200,000 is still to be provided on a project by project basis to a range of organisations. Whether it is the Girl Guides, the Women's Action Alliance, the Women's Electoral Lobby or some other organisation, they are all eligible to apply on a project basis for funding pursuant to this scheme. I and the government believe that this provides ongoing criteria and an ongoing basis for funding over a period of time. This means that the activities carried out by these three major national organisations can be for the greater benefit of the women of Australia yet at the same time provide for projects to be undertaken for specific interest groups—to which the member referred—specific issues or, for that matter, specific areas such as regional or rural parts of Australia so we obtain the best value overall for the good of the people of Australia.

It was noticeable that, when the member for Lilley made this complaint this afternoon, he did not particularise in any way why these groups should not have got the funding. All he said was, `There's been a change in the funding, and isn't this a bad thing,' as though some review by government from time to time is not appropriate. Neither does he mention a whole range of other groups which are funded by the federal government as national peak organisations. I will take a moment or two of the House's time to list those organisations, which are funded to the tune of some $3 million by the Commonwealth government.

You have organisations such as ACOSS. As the minister pointed out before, it is not an organisation which has always been uncritical of this side of politics over the years but nonetheless continues to be funded as a worthwhile organisation. You have ACROD, the Australian Early Childhood Federation, the Australian Federation of Homeless Organisations, the Deafness Forum of Australia, the National Council on Intellectual Disability, Volunteering Australia, the Secretariat of National Aboriginal and Islander Child Care, Family Services Australia, Relationships Australia, Centacare Australia, the National Caucus of Disability Consumer Organisations, the Physical Disability Council of Australia, Women with Disabilities Australia, the National Disability Ethnic Alliance, the Head Injury Council of Australia, the Australian Association of the Deaf, the Federation of Blind Citizens of Australia, the Lone Fathers Association of Australia and the National Council of Single Mothers and Their Children. In total, some 20 organisations are receiving more than $3 million of Commonwealth funding in order to represent particular interests within the community.

This is hardly a government which is defunding a whole range of important programs and a whole range of organisations in the community that are providing a considerable service to the people of Australia at this particular time. When we actually look at the facts rather than the emotive rhetoric and the scaremongering which have been engaged in by the honourable member for Lilley this afternoon, we can see a totally different picture of what has been undertaken by this government.

Some of the members speaking in this debate have mentioned that we should look at welfare again within this country. The interesting thing about this is that it seems to me to be, again, a case of the current opposition simply not being on the ball as far as this is concerned. Let us look at left of centre parties in other countries around the world. If you look at Mr Clinton's administration in the United States of America, you have a President who said a few years ago that he was reforming welfare as we knew it. If you look at what Tony Blair and the Labour government are doing under their new deal in the United Kingdom, you can see a major reform and a major review of welfare going on in that country. It seems to me that the only left of centre party in the industrialised world that is not actually addressing this in any systematic way is the Labor opposition in Australia, and it will pay for not having policies and not having leadership.

What we have in this debate is yesterday's man from yesterday's party arguing yesterday's debate with no eye for the future. In place of this, we need a party with policies and leadership rather than the continual whingeing which we have heard this afternoon. We listened to the member for Lilley's song. Unfortunately, it is not his swan song. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Order! The discussion has concluded.

speech.para: 1 AUSTRALIAN PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO THE THIRD ROUND AUSTRALIA-CHINA BILATERAL HUMAN RIGHTS DIALOGUE : Report on the Australian Delegation to the Third Round Australia-China Bilateral Human Rights Dialogue.

para.inline: The Committee determined that statements on the report may be made—all statements to be made within a total time of 5 minutes.

speech.para: 1 Mr Beazley to present a bill for an act to amend the Defence (Re-establishment) Act 1965 in relation to protection of the civil employment of members of the Reserve Forces. (Notice given 30 September 1999. )

para.inline: Presenter may speak for a period not exceeding 5 minutes—pursuant to sessional order 104A.

speech.para: 2 Mrs Elson to move—
That the House:
(1) recognises the widespread community support for the Government's "Work for the dole" program;
(2) acknowledges the vital role played by the hundreds of community groups and local organisations throughout the nation that conduct local work for the dole projects;
(3) recognises the social value and community contribution of the work carried out by participants; and

(4) welcomes the Government's commitment to expanding Work for the dole, as outlined in the 1999-2000 Budget initiative to double the number of Work for the dole places to 50 000 next year—providing hope, experience and opportunity for more young Australian jobseekers. (Notice given 20 September 1999. )

para.inline: The Committee determined that consideration of this matter should continue on a future day.

speech.para: 3 Mr Mossfield to move—
That this House:
(1) recognises that there needs to be a greater recognition by all adults of the needs of younger people;
(2) recognises that there needs to be a nation-wide recognition that young people can gather together without being regarded as potential law-breakers;

(3) recognises that security personnel need to be far better trained to deal with young people in shopping centres and other public places and that such training enable the security personnel to better determine the correct method of handling young people in public places and shopping centres;

(4) recognises that adults need to be more publicly exposed to young people and listen uncritically to the views they express and respect young people for the views they hold even if they are not agreed with;

(5) recognises that Parliament supports the provision of an increase in technical high schools where young people can expand their practical talents where they are not necessarily academically inclined;

(6) recognises that Parliament recognises the need for increasing dramatically the number of careers advisers available to young people for assistance prior to their leaving school and seeking full time employment; and

(7) conduct a Parliamentary inquiry into the foregoing in order that proper national policies can be recommended to Government that will assist the advancement of young people of the future. (Notice given 27 September 1999. )

para.inline: Time allotted—remaining private Members' business time prior to 1.45 p.m.
The Committee determined that consideration of this matter should continue on a future day.

speech.para: 4 Mrs Elson to move—
That the House:
(1) notes the recent report of he Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission, "Pregnant and Productive: It's a Right not a Privilege to Work while Pregnant";
(2) recognises that a significant level of discrimination against pregnant women still exists in many workplaces;
(3) acknowledges the vital importance of families in Australian society; and

(4) calls on all employers in Australia to be aware of, and sensitive to, their responsibility to their female employees to ensure they do not suffer discrimination on the grounds of pregnancy. (Notice given 30 September 1999. )

para.inline: The Committee determined that consideration of this matter should continue on a future day.

speech.para: 5 Mr Hollis to move—
That this House:
(1) expresses its sympathy at the loss of life of three Australian AusAID workers in the recent air crash in Fiji;
(2) commends AusAID for the work it is performing throughout the South Pacific, especially relating to population and development issues; and
(3) calls on the Australian Government to at least maintain current funding, but also consider increased aid for development work in the South Pacific. (Notice given 26 August 1999. )

para.inline: Time allotted—remaining private Members' business time.
The Committee determined that consideration of this matter should continue on a future day.

debateinfo.title: FURTHER 1998 BUDGET MEASURES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (SOCIAL SECURITY) BILL 1999

subdebateinfo.title: Consideration of Senate Message and Unrelated Amendments

(2) Schedule 2, item 53, page 30 (line 16), omit "19 September 1999", substitute "19 March 2000".
(3) Schedule 8, page 102 (after line 30), after item 1, insert:

; or (e) satisfies the Secretary that the person has moved from his or her original place of residence because of an extreme circumstance which made it reasonable for the person to move to the new place of residence (for example, the person had been subjected to domestic or family violence in the original place of residence).
(4) Schedule 8, page 103 (after line 21), after item 4, insert:
Add:

; or (d) satisfies the Secretary that the person has moved from his or her original place of residence because of an extreme circumstance which made it reasonable for the person to move to the new place of residence (for example, the person had been subjected to domestic or family violence in the original place of residence).
Motion (by Mr Anthony) agreed to:

That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent a Minister moving amendments to the Further 1998 Budget Measures Legislation Amendment (Social Security) Bill 1999 during the consideration of Senate's message No. 195.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation for the purpose of requests for amendments announced.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the requested amendments be made.

The Senate recently made a number of amendments to the Further 1998 Budget Measures Legislation Amendment (Social Security) Bill 1999 . Amendments (1) and (2) ensure that the correct calculations of income reductions for those persons who are receiving both a youth disability supplement payment as well as a Community Development Employment Projects, CDEP, payment. Amendment (3) is a technical amendment. There are no further financial implications for these amendments.

Today we are talking about three minor technical amendments. However, I believe it appropriate to inform the House of another amendment to this bill that the government will not be supporting. The amendment put forward by the Democrats relating to the CDEP scheme and lone parents also receiving parenting payment (single) is nonsensical. The Democrat amendment effectively creates a grandfather clause in relation to existing lone parents so that they would forever be unaffected by the new provisions.

A more considered review of these amendments has shown that, for a number of technical reasons, the Democrats' apparent objective is not achieved by the amendments. Firstly, the insertion of the provision to exclude recipients of parenting payment (single) from the operations of items 48 to 52 of schedule 2 is ineffective, items 48 to 52 impacting on parenting payment (partnered) and non-partnered payment (single). Further, the provision as it relates to item 53 of schedule 2 prevents lone parents from receiving their CDEP income supplement. It also disallows CDEP participants from receiving their supplement for any future payment they transfer to. This would result in a group of people who have never been eligible for the CDEP payment supplement, irrespective of whether they are on income support or what payments they are qualified for.

There are strong policy reasons for avoiding a grandfathering approach to the income treatment of lone parents. A grandfathering clause is inconsistent with the welfare reform intended by the measure; that is, greater equity for CDEP participants in this measure has the strong support of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. The measure supported by ATSIC ends the situation where a small group of people are able to legally claim and keep two income support payments. No-one else in the Australian community is legally able to double-dip from the taxpayer. For this reason, the government is not supportive of these particular Senate amendments.

talk.start.para: —I rise to object to the government's attempt to eliminate the amendment which was successfully carried by the Senate in relation to the CDEP scheme and sole parents. I find it quite astonishing that a government that says it supports Work for the Dole, that says it supports single parents and that says it supports indigenous Australians could come into this House and object to the amendment to its original bill which was carried in the Senate.

speech.para: The ALP moved in the Senate that the attempt to slash assistance to indigenous sole parents be not supported at all. It is with some reluctance that we agreed to the Democrat position, which was to create a two-tiered system whereby beneficiaries who were currently eligible would not lose this money and whereby the new application would apply to only new participants in CDEP. We need to examine the government's rhetoric on this, and then we need to compare it to the reality.

The government's rhetoric is that somehow this allows welfare double dipping. That is not true, Minister. In fact, what this scheme does is ensure that sole parents who are on the CDEP are treated the same as other sole parents; that is, that they are allowed, on top of their parenting payment, to receive up to $100 a fortnight as a result of their working. Indigenous sole parents working is an important principle. It encourages them to participate fully in society. It also means that of the $330 which the individual is paid by contributing to the CDEP scheme and participating in that scheme, the individual sole parent gets only $100 per fortnight, which means that there is $230 put into that community.

We know that the CDEP is paid to indigenous communities. It has been extraordinarily successful and has gained widespread support, in spite of the government setting up an inquiry into the CDEP scheme when it was first elected and in spite of the fact that this government's first action upon coming to office was to slash $450 million from ATSIC. So given the previous debate which we had, where the shadow minister, the member for Lilley, spoke about the 30 groups who have had their funding cut, perhaps that explains to the minister ATSIC's position in relation to this matter.

The fact is that this is a government which is prepared to intimidate any group in our society that objects to its uncaring, selfish agenda. This is a government that is never happier than when it is kicking the most vulnerable in our society—and who is more vulnerable than indigenous sole parents? The fact is that this government is not interested in actually participating in giving people a helping hand up to contribute to society. This government, by not supporting this amendment, wants to slash $80 a fortnight off indigenous sole parents. Minister, $80 a fortnight might not be much to you and your frontbench colleagues, with your family trusts, but it matters a lot to indigenous sole parents. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I fully support the comments made by the member for Grayndler here today. I think it is outrageous that this government, which prides itself on looking after the indigenous brethren of this country, is ripping into them by opposing the very sensible amendments carried in the Senate in relation to the Community Development Employment Program. We know that this program is designed to help the Aboriginal community. It was established in 1977 so that members of the Aboriginal community could effectively work for the dole on projects which were beneficial to their community. The government's opposition to the amendments is disgraceful. As the member for Grayndler has just said, this is a vicious attack on the most vulnerable in the community—indigenous sole parents.

speech.para: I thought this government was interested in doing everything possible to help indigenous members of our community to get into employment and to give them every possible opportunity to make a contribution to this country, but this is quite a callous act. What the Senate has sought to achieve by trying to help those participating in this program is in the interests of not only the Aboriginal community but all of Australia.

Interestingly, the research done by Anne Daly demonstrates the enormous socioeconomic disadvantages for indigenous sole parents. Ms Daly's research revealed that indigenous sole parents were almost twice as likely to be unemployed compared with non-indigenous sole parents, that indigenous sole parents were responsible for caring for 40 per cent of all indigenous children, that indigenous sole parents were earning less money than non-indigenous sole parents while caring for more children, that indigenous sole parents were bearing extra financial burden due to care given to foster children, often without government income support and, further, that indigenous sole parents were less likely to be educated compared with other indigenous families and non-indigenous sole parents.

The government is trying to save a few bob here at the expense of the very people we are elected in this House to look after. All we are trying to do is give them an opportunity to contribute to Australia and get paid for it. Through callous efforts, the government is opposing these very sensible amendments that took place in the Senate. It is noteworthy that, since 1966, the government seems to have had a whole agenda of getting stuck into those on welfare payments. It has more of a priority for creating jobs and a social security safety net than for meeting the disadvantaged people in our community. Recently, the Prime Minister and Senator Newman ruled out further cuts to welfare. It is going to continue, and it is disgraceful. We have to oppose it here today. I do not support what the government is trying to achieve through amendments to the CDEP, the employment and education entry payment and the liquid asset waiting period. I will talk about them very briefly in the short time that is left.

Firstly, those on the CDEP are ineligible for a range of ancillary benefits, including rent assistance, bereavement payments, telephone rental allowance, pharmaceutical allowance and pensioner concession cards. Secondly, it is estimated that as many as 4,000 sole parents on the CDEP are now going to have further unfair measures placed on them. The present arrangements will see eligibility for parenting payments reduced for every dollar of CDEP income up to the amount of the parenting payment benefit. The parenting payment would also be reduced by something like 50 per cent for each dollar of CDEP income in excess of the parenting payment threshold. This is disgraceful. We have to support the amendments. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise again to reinforce the opposition's concern about this issue.
—You like the sound of your own voice.

—The Minister for Community Services might not care about indigenous sole parents. Perhaps we can put something on the Hansard record to inform him and the government exactly whom they are kicking. A bit of research has been done on indigenous sole parents and what they represent in society. That research from census data shows the following: that indigenous sole parents are almost twice as likely to be unemployed compared with non-indigenous sole parents; that they are responsible for caring for 40 per cent of all indigenous children due to the culture—a culture of looking after children who are not necessarily their own by parentage; that they earn less money than non-indigenous sole parents while caring for more children; that they bear extra financial burdens due to care given to foster children, often without government support; and that they are less likely to be educated compared with other indigenous families and non-indigenous sole parents. So, Minister, who better to single out for a kick than indigenous sole parents?

speech.para: The Minister for Family and Community Services, Senator Newman, has raised this matter. One would think that this would be incongruous for the minister. How can the minister support this attack, taking $80 per fortnight from these Australians? Let us have a look at Senator Newman's attitude towards single parents. You do not have to quote the Minister for Community Services or even the Attorney-General, but let us quote the minister herself. This is extraordinary. This is the minister just after she had to abandon her great welfare announcement. Just after she put that in the bottom drawer, this is what she had to say on the ABC radio's Life Matters :

. . . the 32% of the mothers with children between the ages of 10 and 14 (who do not work) are either quite wealthy or they have no skills to offer and no confidence to try to be like all other women.

What a disgraceful comment from the Minister for Family and Community Services. What a disgraceful comment from the graduate from the Margaret Thatcher school of kicking beggars. What a disgraceful position from a minister who talks about compassion.

The opposition will be supporting the Democrat amendments in the Senate when this bill goes back there. We will be supporting those because we have been consistently of the view that the people who are singled out for cuts in order to fund tax benefits for the big end of town in the government's Ralph review, in the GST changes and in the income tax cuts should not be single parents, should not be indigenous Australians and should not be the disabled.

Every time the government has a look at this issue, it is as if it gains pleasure from attacking the most vulnerable people in our society. It says it is doing it for consistency, but that is just not true. Consistency requires that indigenous people be allowed—as non-indigenous people on parenting payments are allowed—to earn up to $100 a fortnight. Non-indigenous people are allowed to do it, Minister. Why are indigenous Australians being singled out? They are being singled out because of the One Nation type agenda being pursued by the government when it comes to the issue of race and when it comes to the issue of the most vulnerable in our society. Right now, single parents can use the CDEP to supplement income. What is wrong with that, Minister? What is wrong with indigenous Australians being encouraged to contribute to their community? (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I stand here amazed by some of the remarks from members of the opposition. They are basically supporting double-dipping. They are saying that it is okay to double-dip. The interesting point with the moralistic sort of stand that some members of the opposition are taking is that, if we were so wrong, why is it that ATSIC and the leadership of ATSIC are supporting these amendments? ATSIC has always being known to be fiercely independent in its views of government policy, and we accept that. But ATSIC is accepting the amendments. The amendments have strong support from the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. It seems as though the Labor Party is not listening to that. It is not listening to this peak organisation which we recognise looks after indigenous Australians—who have been disadvantaged for many years—and which acknowledges of itself that this policy of not double-dipping is correct and that the amendments that have been moved by the Democrats in the Senate are wrong.

speech.para: Yet members of the Labor Party are trying to beat up this little story of our being uncaring and not being supportive when the facts are that the indigenous community recognise that the amendments that are being proposed are wrong. The CDEP scheme has been operating for many years—well before Work for the Dole. Indeed, the fact it has been working so well is one reason we decided to extend the mutual obligation principle to many other members of the community. But, historically, there has been an anomaly that lone parents on CDEP schemes could legally claim their CDEP wages plus their pension payments.

The opposition are saying that that is okay and are encouraging people to double-dip. We do not believe that is correct. People should be entitled to their payments but only their entitlements. Even when the same well-respected indigenous organisation, ATSIC, says that it agrees that the amendments are wrong, the opposition conveniently forget this, for political purposes and point scoring. The government acknowledge this. We are not backwards; we do not try to politicise this, as the member for Grayndler unfortunately does. He is stooping to university style politics.

The government acknowledges the considerable disadvantage faced by indigenous lone parents. However, it does not believe that double-dipping is a satisfactory solution. Both the board of ATSIC and Ian Spicer, who conducted an independent review of the CDEP scheme in 1997, believe this double-dipping loophole should be changed. Indigenous lone parents do receive assistance through other measures—we recognise that—such as the Jobs, Education and Training program, JET. For instance, JET funding has enabled creches to be set up by the CDEP scheme to train child-care workers in indigenous communities. In some cases, it has led to permanent child-care centres operating and other innovative child-care solutions. After the changes, lone parents will still be better off participating in the CDEP than remaining solely on income support. They will also remain slightly better off financially than other CDEP participants.

Access to CDEP is being extended to all other pensioners for the first time under this measure. It is a good measure. Age and disability support pensioners have been eager to participate in the scheme, and extending the current treatment of the CDEP income to these pensioners will create further disparities between customers in similar circumstances. Quite frankly, the Labor Party are not even going to divide on this bill. If they feel so passionately about it, maybe they should. Underneath it all, they are just playing politics, and they are recognising that double-dipping should not be supported by any members of the community. And it should not be supported by the opposition.

The whole reason we try to have a very open and transparent welfare system is so that people who are entitled to that assistance receive it, whether they are indigenous Australians or any other Australians. But we do not support double-dipping, and neither would the opposition if it were open and transparent about this. It is whipping up a storm in a teacup for pure political purposes. Even ATSIC, the premier organisation and peak body that looks after indigenous people in this country, recognises that this anomaly is incorrect and unfair for other Australian taxpayers. It acknowledges that the opportunistic amendments moved by the Democrats, with the tacit support of the Labor Party, are wrong.

talk.start.para: —One thing I have learnt this afternoon is that the Minister for Community Services has absolutely no idea how the CDEP operates or, indeed, where it operates. Nor has he any idea of the conditions in which people who are participants in the CDEP live. I doubt whether he has ever seen a CDEP community, and he comes in here and waxes lyrical about the sorts of services that are available to single parents in remote communities where the CDEP operates.

speech.para: You are living in cloud-cuckoo-land, brother. You have absolutely no comprehension about what life is like for people who live on CDEP in my communities. You have absolutely no idea about the level of poverty that people are subject to when they live in these communities. You have no idea at all about the lack of universality of services—about the services which do not apply in those communities. I just heard you talk about how JET operates in Aboriginal communities. I suppose you will tell me that your employment programs generally operate in Aboriginal communities. Let me tell you that they do not. In fact, the net result of the efforts of your government over successive budgets has been to whip out the funding not only from ATSIC but from those other agencies that provide the sorts of support services that you were just waxing lyrical about.

There is no doubt about it: the most disadvantaged people in Australia, bar none, are the people living in severe poverty in these Aboriginal communities who are subject to CDEP. In reference to that level of disadvantage, studies by the Northern Territory Department of Health have demonstrated that the cost of living is higher for the people who live in those remote communities where they get the privilege, which they themselves have accepted since 1972, to work for the dole—nothing more. The cost, on average, of a simple basket of goods in most of these communities in remote Northern Australia is 140 per cent of the cost of a basket of goods in Sydney or Melbourne. What you are planning to do by these proposals is whip out $80 per fortnight in income and assistance to some of these people. You should understand the impact of this on these communities.

You, along with your government, continue to talk about your concerns for young Australians, single parents and indigenous Australians. Well, we have never seen the colour of your money. We are seeing here an effort by you and by your government to withhold from these Australians their legitimate rights, to withhold from them their legitimate needs that should be being met by your government. In some measly-minded way, you believe that somehow or other they are double-dipping. Let me tell you: they are being treated no differently from other sole parents. That is what the equation should be about: their treatment vis-a-vis other Australians. I have the privilege, and have had the privilege, of knowing many of these single parents. I understand and know how difficult it is for these people to make ends meet. I know how hard it is for these people to put clothes on their children's backs and shoes on their children's feet and to supply appropriate nutrition because of the level of geographic isolation they suffer and the cost that they incur as a result.

What you are proposing to do now is further undermine that ability to provide these essentials of life for their children. That is what the test is about: whether it is reasonable and whether it is fair. It is very clear that it is neither reasonable nor fair. It is just another extension of the attitude of your government, historically and until now, and of your disparaging attitude towards those people who live in remote Australia generally and, most particularly in this instance, towards those people who are on CDEP. I ask you, Minister: if you really are sincere about understanding these things, go and look at the impact of the decisions that are being made by your government in terms of the withdrawal of services, in particular and in general, from these remote communities as a result of financial stringency and the budget cuts being made by you and your government.

talk.start.para: —I note that the Minister for Community Services, in defending this callous action by the government, has quoted ATSIC. I want to quote ATSIC myself, from the letter that they wrote to the Leader of the Australian Democrats on 31 December 1999, signed by Gatjil Djerrkura, the Chairman of ATSIC:

speech.para: While the Board has expressed concern over the potential impact of the new income arrangements for lone parents, pensioners on CDEP . . .

There it is: ATSIC themselves have expressed concern. But, because this government has a take it or leave it approach and because of the way it disguises cuts as reforms, ATSIC were once again put in the position of: `Here is the package—take it or you get nothing.'

The ALP moved a number of amendments in the Senate to this bill. We fixed up the crisis payment and the changes that the government was proposing in knocking off the education and employment entry payments. We fixed it up so that there will now be a choice of either getting that one-off payment or having a loan of between $50 and $400. We also fixed up the pensioner education supplement issue. In fact, we have fixed up a number of the inadequacies with this bill. But one of the things that we also moved on was this issue. I have said to the minister that we would have preferred that it not be subject to a time frame. We would have preferred this move to have just been knocked off completely because, as ATSIC themselves say, there is no doubt that people will leave this scheme as a result. If you take away any financial incentive whatsoever for people to participate in the CDEP—so that instead of getting $100 a fortnight, they get $20 a fortnight—you say to them: `Don't bother; don't bother trying to improve your situation or trying to contribute to your community because we do not believe that you should participate.' The inequity in this is just extraordinary. The double-dipping argument is false.

The fact is that other people who are receiving parenting payments can earn up to $102 per fortnight. The difference with this scheme is that they are actually earning $330, not $100. Therefore, $230 remains with the communities in which they are contributing, and only $100 per fortnight goes into their own pocket and into the mouths of the children they have to feed. This government and this minister want to take the food out of those children's mouths. This government wants to take the clothes off those children's backs. It wants to take the books off those children. If you were to think of who in our community would be the most vulnerable, where would you begin but with indigenous sole parents in remote areas? It is just extraordinary that this minister and this government speak about these people ripping off the taxpayer. I am sorry, Minister, but here we are speaking of 4,000 indigenous sole parents who have been subjected to 200 years of discrimination—and you say to them, `We're going to take $80 off you.' Minister, you are joking!

talk.start.para: —Get off your high horse.

—The minister says, `Get off your high horse.' Minister, we will continue to stand by these indigenous sole parents because we know that this grubby, uncaring government, made up of graduates of the Thatcher institute for kicking beggars, does not care about these people. This government is looking for budget savings measures wherever it can get them. Then it will be able to fix up its tax cuts for the big end of town. It will be able to reduce capital gains tax. It will be able to put in place all these measures for the wealthiest in society whom it represents whilst, at the same time, introducing this pitiful measure for the meagre savings it will bring.

speech.para: Motion (by Mr Anthony) agreed to:
That the question be now put.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: (1) Schedule 2, item 53, page 22 (table item 3, 4th column), after "1066A-B1", insert "(including any amount required to be added by point 1066A-C1)".
(2) Schedule 2, item 53, page 23 (table item 4, 4th column), after "1066A-B1", insert "(including any amount required to be added by point 1066A-C1)".
(3) Schedule 2, item 54, page 39 (line 31), omit "1231A(1A) ", substitute "1231(1A) ".
I table the supplementary explanatory memorandum.
Amendments agreed to.
Motion (by Mr Anthony) agreed to:
That, in the message returning the bill to the Senate, the Senate be requested to reconsider the bill in respect of the amendments made by the House of Representatives to the bill.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 2 September, on motion by Mr Williams:
That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The opposition will not be opposing the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill 1999 , but I will make a couple of points in the course of the debate. The bill itself is relatively straightforward, but the issues which it traverses are frequently and appropriately controversial and sensitive. In particular, this legislation relates to the regulation of information obtained with search warrants through, as the title of the bill says, telecommunications interception. The international community, as we would expect, generally is concerned about how this area is regulated. Clearly, society has an interest in effective law enforcement, but equally that has to be balanced against the rights of individuals.

speech.para: For instance, article 17 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights provides:
1. No one shall be subjected to arbitrary or unlawful interference with his privacy, family, home or correspondence, nor to unlawful attacks on his honour or reputation.
2. Everyone has the right to the protection of the law against such interference and attacks.

The provisions of article 8, the European Convention on Human Rights, are also to similar effect in a little more detail. So the international community, in respect of multilateral treaties, has recognised the balance required between enabling proper law enforcement activities and protecting the rights of the individual. That has usually been obtained by ensuring that the executive action of implementing a warrant is firstly scrutinised by a member of the judiciary who is separate from the executive level of government.

The problem occurred where, after a High Court case in 1995 of Grollo v. Commissioner of Australian Federal Police, a number of Federal Court judges indicated their concern about issuing search warrants. Increasingly they were finding themselves on cases reviewing the administrative action of implementing those warrants, and they were concerned that their involvement in the issuing of those warrants compromised their ability to adjudicate. So, as a result of that, the government extended the ability to issue warrants to selected members of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. I will talk about those issues a little later in the debate.

The first series of amendments that the bill proposes are really to include the Anti-Corruption Commission of West Australia among those agencies entitled to receive this intercepted information. It essentially deals with corruption, crime and serious improper conduct of public officers. The opposition has no objection to that agency being declared under section 34 as an appropriate agency to receive information. The second agency is the Queensland Crime Commission, which has responsibility to investigate criminal paedophilia and organised crime generally. Again, the opposition recognises the gravity of those matters. We have no objection to that body being declared as an appropriate organisation to receive information. The amendments will entitle those two bodies to receive the information where it appears to relate to the conduct that they are investigating, where the use of the intercepted information is undertaken in accordance with its functions or its charters and also, where provided—and importantly provided—the Attorney-General first issues a declaration under section 34 of the Telecommunications (Interception) Act to obtain warrants to intercept telecommunications. And there are a number of requirements before those declarations are issued.

As I indicated earlier, section 103A of the Telecommunications (Interception) Act required a review to be undertaken of the power of Administrative Appeals Tribunal members or certain identified and selected members to issue warrants. At the time, the opposition supported the power being extended to members of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal on the basis that there was a sunset provision which expires in December of this year and subject to review.

The government set up the Telecommunications Interception Policy Review of the operation of the act and specifically the issuing of these warrants by members of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The review has recently been tabled in parliament. The proposed amendment will effectively remove that sunset provision which will, on an ongoing basis, enable the minister to continue to nominate specified members of the AAT to issue interception warrants for law enforcement purposes. There are indeed qualifications imposed in the selection of those specific AAT members, specifically that they have to have legal qualifications and appropriate experience.

While the Australian Labor Party have reservations about the use of members of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal to issue warrants, we acknowledge that the experience has largely proved positive. We must place on the record that we do have some concerns regarding the readiness of members of the AAT to issue warrants but note that this is largely being addressed as those members gain experience of the warrant process. Nonetheless it is very important to ensure that they are fully aware of what is required from them; otherwise there is not that independent scrutiny of the executive action or executive request if the person issuing the warrant is not fully aware of their responsibilities.

We are also concerned that some agencies are preferring to obtain warrants from members of the AAT rather than from available Federal Court judges. We strongly believe that it is still preferable for judges to be approached first when a warrant is sought. Indeed, we read that as also being consistent with the views of the policy review, to which I have referred earlier. By and large, particularly in the circumstances where Federal Court judges themselves were apprehensive about issuing warrants, we are prepared to support this bill both in respect of the inclusion of the agencies to which I have referred and also in respect of removing that sunset provision and providing the ongoing power for members of the AAT to issue warrants.

The three points I want to address in the discussion are as follows: firstly, the relationship between the government and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and whether it will be appropriate for a similar power to be bestowed upon members of the Administrative Review Tribunal which the government is contemplating establishing; secondly, whether the range of offences for which a warrant can be obtained are sufficiently defined and appropriate constraints placed on the use of telecommunications interception devices for serious offences; and, thirdly, the need for the supervision of the exchange of information between agencies.

The first point to note is that, as I have indicated, under section DA of the Telecommunications (Interception) Act the Attorney-General has the power to authorise named persons to issue warrants. As I have indicated, they have to have necessary qualifications. They have to be a legally qualified legal practitioner of at least five years standing to be nominated as a person who is appropriate to issue warrants. Again, the fact of the security of tenure of members of the AAT separates them sufficiently from the executive to make them appropriate officers to undertake this very serious and significant task of permitting warrants to be issued.

But we are concerned about the government's proposal to introduce legislation establishing the Administrative Review Tribunal. The discussion paper associated with that proposal has been released. The primary distinguishing features of the Administrative Review Tribunal are that members of the tribunal will, if the government's intention goes ahead, be likely to come from those departments that they are involved in and there will not be the same necessary qualification restrictions on those members. Also, importantly, they will have short-term contracts before returning to the bureaucracy or the executive arm of government.

We are of the view that those persons are not likely to be sufficiently qualified to undertake this important and serious task, nor are they sufficiently separated from the function of the executive to be impartial in reviewing the request by the executive to issue warrants. Accordingly, we put the government firmly on notice that, while we are prepared to agree to members of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal having the power to issue warrants, we will be drawing a line in the sand when—or if—it comes to the establishment of an administrative review tribunal. Indeed, we note that if such a tribunal is established to replace the Administrative Appeals Tribunal it will be necessary to amend the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979, and we put the government on notice that we would not accept that as an appropriate amendment.

So in those circumstances the government would do well to heed the recommendations of the Telecommunications Interception Policy Review, which recommended that in respect of the appointment of Federal Court judges it first be ascertained whether those Federal Court judges would be prepared to be nominated or declared as an appropriate person to issue warrants. Again, it is the view of the Australian Labor Party that wherever possible it should be a member of the judiciary that supervises the issuing of these warrants, for that very important reason. They are obviously qualified lawyers, they are experienced in the rules of evidence and, most importantly, they are quite separate and have security of tenure. They are separate and distinct from the executive government, which is issuing these warrants to impinge on the liberty of members of the community.

The second issue which I indicated required examination was whether the offences for the issuing of warrants are sufficiently defined and sufficiently serious. There is also a related issue as to whether those seeking warrants and being approved to issue warrants are doing them bona fide, having regard to the seriousness of the matters which they are required to investigate.

We note that concern has been expressed in recent weeks about the use by certain state anticorruption authorities of telecommunications interception warrants to investigate offences, potential offences or potential corrupt acts that may not be sufficiently serious to justify the action that they have taken. For instance, it appears that the New South Wales Independent Commission against Corruption has issued warrants for the interception of the telephones of members of parliament—perhaps not going into Parliament House itself, but certainly, it appears, their electorate offices.

That is a very serious situation, because it does have the potential to affect the ability of members of parliament to fulfil their privileged responsibility of representing their constituents. Clearly, if telephones are being intercepted, they are recording not only statements made by the member of parliament but complaints coming in from constituents. That sort of situation is obviously a very serious intervention in the privacy of those people, particularly the constituents who are contacting their members of parliament, and one which should occur only for very serious offences.

Section 45 of the act provides that the warrants can be issued in respect of class 1 offences, which are defined in section 5 of the act to include very serious offences, such as murder, kidnapping or a narcotics offence. Again, any reasonable Australian would say it is appropriate that our law enforcement authorities have the power to intercept telephones in those circumstances. Section 46 provides for the issuing of warrants in respect of class 2 offences, which are defined in section 5D of the act. Class 2 offences include offences punishable by a maximum period of at least seven years, and relate to various types of criminal conduct and also other specified offences, usually involving serious corruption. So, by definition, an offence having the potential maximum period of penal servitude of seven years is in the nature of a serious offence and appropriately included in the schedule. We note that that schedule has not changed since the period of the former Labor government in 1995.

Also, there is the added safeguard in respect of the issuing of warrants for class 2 offences by a judge or member of the AAT that the member must consider, among other matters, the gravity of the offence. Again, we say that is appropriate. As one would expect, a warrant also exists in respect of an offence that is ancillary to those class 1 or class 2 offences. That would include matters such as aiding and abetting one or other of those offences. But they are, again, those serious offences as set out in the provisions of the act to which I have referred.

Further, anticorruption agencies may only investigate a prescribed offence, with the term being defined in section 5 to include serious offences punishable by a maximum period of at least three years and also ancillary offences. A serious offence is defined as a class 1 or class 2 offence as listed above. We note again that those provisions are the same as they have been for a long time, since 1987—again enacted by the previous Labor government.

In summary, the range of offences for which a telecommunications interception warrant can be used has not been significantly altered in recent years. The only thing that has changed has been the range of agencies than can apply for a warrant and, again, only in respect of those matters involving serious criminality and serious corruption.

So the Labor Party is determined—as I hope all members of parliament would be—to ensure that any alleged abuse of the warrant process should be fully investigated. It is a serious matter, a serious infringement of basic human rights, and one which requires an appropriately and effectively functioning independent investigative agency to review these matters. At the federal level there is the Commonwealth Ombudsman, and each state has established an agency to act in a similar role. While these arrangements go a long way to addressing the concerns which we have raised about the use of warrants, we believe that they are not in themselves a comprehensive solution.

We believe that the Commonwealth should advocate for the establishment of a national inspecting authority coordinating committee to review the operation of the warrant process and to develop a national code setting out the principles of best practice in issuing and using these warrants and the material obtained from the use of these warrants. This committee will help to ensure consistency of practice in the undertaking of those particular functions. Again, that is consistent with a recommendation of the policy review committee, although that committee was perhaps too limited in talking about the coordinating authority reviewing, in particular, the use of encryption technology. But we say there is a need for that coordination between the Commonwealth and state investigative agencies to develop best practice models and procedures applicable to these law enforcement agencies.

That relates to the third and final point, about the exchange of information. These agencies are entitled to notify, and one would expect that, if they became aware of a serious offence or act of corruption that was not perhaps within their area of responsibility or within their charter, they would have in mind the public interest and duly notify the agency or agencies that had the responsibility to investigate that particular area of criminal activity or corruption. Again, it is very important that such information only be exchanged with respect to the same scrutiny that is necessary when we are contemplating issuing a warrant.

We note that there are procedures in the act whereby under section 68 these exchanges can take place only from one chief executive to the chief executive of another agency or by a person duly authorised by the chief executive to either give or receive the information. And it is important that the information not be exchanged without that senior level of supervision. We also note that information can be lawfully exchanged only where it appears to relate to a relevant offence in relation to that agency. The term `relevant offence' is defined in section 5 of the act to include a proscribed offence particular to the relevant agency. Again, we would think that is appropriate. It would be one thing for an interception to detect an official or a criminal using an SP bookmaker, as it is clearly an illegal activity; but to communicate that fact to an agency which did not have responsibility for investigating racing and gaming may be inappropriate.

These controls are very important and more so is the application of principles and the need to oversee how that information is exchanged. At the Commonwealth level there is the Commonwealth Ombudsman, and each state government has similar inspecting authorities. Again, we say that it is appropriate for the Commonwealth to take a leading role in establishing a coordinating committee to review the exchange of this information. It is relatively easy for the Attorney-General to exercise that role because, before he makes a declaration in respect of an agency that that particular agency is duly authorised to receive information under section 35 of the act, the Attorney-General is required to be satisfied that the relevant agency will report to the Attorney-General on its application and use of warrants under the act and also will be subject to scrutiny by a suitably empowered and independent state inspecting authority. While we think that those mechanisms are appropriate, they most certainly could be enhanced with respect to the area of the transfer of information, and we would call on the Attorney-General most certainly to review those matters.

Finally, I note that it is appropriate—and I expect that the government will arrange this—for the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills to examine the bill. That committee has a special position in the parliament—one often underestimated and underrated. It has a responsibility to review these bills and to report to parliament as to whether they will `trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties' of individuals; whether they will `make rights, liberties or obligations unduly dependent upon insufficiently defined administrative powers'; whether they will `make rights, liberties or obligations unduly dependent upon non-reviewable decisions'; whether they involve an inappropriate delegation of legislative power; and, finally, whether they will `insufficiently subject the exercise of legislative power to parliamentary scrutiny'.

While that function is important and will, as a matter of course, take place in respect of a bill such as this, I noticed in the press yesterday that there was an article regarding the potential use of interception power so that a warrant would not be directed at a particular technology but rather at an individual. The very sophisticated technologies we have now for intercepting phone calls, email communications, tracing vehicles and distant tracking devices all have the potential to be very seriously invasive of not only that person who is the subject of investigation but also those persons with whom they are dealing. They have the potential therefore to affect all members of the community.

As we are looking at the need to provide our law enforcement agencies with cutting edge technology to undertake their task I think the time is coming for us to also examine and more fully state the rights, of individuals. It is coming very close to the time when this parliament should again be looking at the appropriateness of at least a statutory bill of rights, which could beef up and make more significant those sorts of principles that the Senate committee to which I have referred takes on board when it reviews legislation. Insofar as these are matters which are very significant when we are looking at the executive interfering in and intruding into the lives of our citizens, we cannot take the responsibility too lightly. Having said that, we think this bill is appropriate in that it removes a sunset provision and extends what is already occurring on an indefinite basis, and the two agencies which will be declared agencies are appropriate law enforcement agencies to be so declared. The opposition will support this bill.

talk.start.para: —This Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill 1999 deals with telecommunications interception and aims to strengthen the ability of Australian law enforcement agencies to deal with paedophilia, organised crime and corruption by public officials. The interception of telecommunications by law enforcement agencies and the subsequent use of intercepted information are regulated by the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979. This bill amends the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979 to include the Anti-Corruption Commission of Western Australia and the Queensland Crime Commission as `eligible authorities' under the act.

speech.para: It is unquestioned that we live in an age where there have been enormous advances in telecommunications, and no country has been more ready to embrace changes in telecommunications than Australia. I note the shadow minister's caution in his address that as these various forms of telecommunications converge we have to be vigilant that they do not become intrusive into the lives of ordinary Australians. Improvements in communications and telecommunication have had a profound effect on the quality of our lives and the way we do business. Just consider how the average telephone has changed in the last 12 years—to say nothing of the mobile phone. I can remember winning a mobile phone about eight or nine years ago, and it was a great big bulky thing; today you can slip one into your pocket and it is scarcely discernible. Shortly, more opportunities will be opened up to us with satellite mobile phones.

Soon, nowhere in Australia will be remote from telephony. While this provides enormous benefits for legitimate business and we can use phones in a variety of ways—recorded messages, call-backs and diversion call facilities right through now to data transfer, just to name a few of the possibilities—we also have to recognise that our current era of telecommunications expansion has enhanced the opportunity for criminals and perverts to harness this medium and to hide behind its relative confidentiality. In the future, someone smuggling drugs or illicit pornographic material—or even smuggling human cargo—will be able to be in the loop of the most sophisticated telecommunications in the most remote parts of our coastline. So I suppose it is appropriate that the government cautiously widens the agencies and the limits under which they can operate.

Like the shadow Attorney, I am a great libertarian. I always view with the utmost scepticism anything that limits the freedom of the individual or intrudes into his or her privacy. There is nothing more abhorrent to any Australian than the thought that someone might be illegally listening to his or her conversation. Many people come into my electorate office when they suspect this is happening—whether it is being done legally or illegally, and they usually suspect it is illegal. In fact, people can be quite paranoid about it, quite disturbed.

Quite rightly, we have always had very strict laws regarding intercepting and recording conversations, and any move we make to impinge on this principle needs to be measured against the right of privacy on the one hand and the greater community good on the other. Prior to 1960, there was no prohibition on the interception of telephonic communications, although some activities, such as interference with telephone lines, would have constituted an offence. The general prohibition on interception was introduced in 1960 with exemptions from the prohibition for interceptions relating to offences against post and telegraph legislation and for national security purposes—where warrants were issued but only to ASIO. The Telecommunications (Interception) Act of 1979 extends the range of matters on which interception warrants could be issued to include narcotics offences punishable under the Customs Act 1901. This principal act also extends the service which could be intercepted to include data transmission. Although, like the shadow Attorney, I have misgivings about that in some respects, I can understand that sophisticated criminals—just taking those three examples before of people introducing narcotics or pornographic material or even human cargo into this country—would have those sophisticated means at their disposal.

The last major change in this area occurred in 1987 when the ability to apply for an interception warrant was extended to more general serious offences and to state law enforcement agencies. The bill today widens the power of interception but within fairly limited parameters. For example, with regard to potential offences, these amendments mean that agencies other than ASIO can use interception to investigate class 1 and class 2 offences, as they are known. Class 1 offences include murder, kidnapping, the transportation of narcotics and conspiracy emanating from those three crimes. Class 2 offences include a range of offences punishable by a maximum penalty of seven or more years. Examples include money laundering offences, offences relating to Commonwealth computers and data, and serious bribery.

As the end of the millennium approaches, we have all been sensitised to the Y2K phenomenon. We recognise that the malfunctioning of computers, for example, is a matter of the greatest gravity. We can well understand why, over time, the bill has been expanded to include artificial tampering with computers, especially where they relate to government services. That should attract our concern and penalties for those offences should reflect that concern.

Going back to the amendments themselves, this mode of interception can only occur when a warrant is issued by a judge of a court created by the Commonwealth parliament or a member of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, while ASIO can also be issued with warrants by the Attorney-General and the Director-General of Security. I would like to take up a point that the shadow Attorney made. I find it a little disturbing that members of the Federal Court forgo the right to issue these warrants. I have some ambivalence to these things being handed to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, not that I have any problem with the tribunal itself, but it seems to me that we empowered the Federal Court to carry out a number of functions, and judges of that court are fairly senior in the legal hierarchy of this country and for them to forgo this responsibility disturbs me somewhat. I would like to think that judges—before forgoing this responsibility—would take a more serious look at it. I would much prefer to see these things in the hands of the judiciary. I agree that the second-best choice is someone in the AAT with five years legal experience.

The organisations currently eligible to apply to carry out such interceptions include the Australian Federal Police, the National Crime Authority, the Victorian, New South Wales, South Australian and Western Australian police forces, the New South Wales Crime Commission, the Independent Commission Against Corruption and the Police Integrity Commission of New South Wales. The amendments proposed will mean the Queensland Crime Commission and the Anti-Corruption Commission of Western Australia will be included within the definition of eligible authorities for the purposes of the principal act.

The QCC was first established in 1997 to investigate and gain evidence relating to relevant criminal activity referred to it by its management committee. Relevant criminal activity includes paedophilia, crimes punishable by imprisonment of 14 years or more and organised crime. Paedophilia is an issue of utmost concern in Queensland following recent court cases. It is a matter that causes people on both sides of politics in Queensland great angst. I, for one, support the extension of this power to the QCC.
