In Western Australia, the ACC was established in 1988 to receive or initiate allegations of corruption about police officers or other public officials and to investigate these allegations. The amendments will enable these agencies to receive and use intercepted information originally obtained by other law enforcement agencies where the information relates to matters that the agency investigate. I too have ambivalence about the exchange of that information, and I think we should periodically review this legislation to make sure that it does not get watered down in such a way that someone indulging in a bit of SP bookmaking—to use the example used by the shadow Attorney—is picked up as a consequence of some other investigation and finds that that information becomes available to other law enforcement agencies. That is not the purpose of this act and we should make sure that this act is never watered down to include such matters. As we all know, there is a tendency, once a privilege is extended, for intrusion into people's civil rights and for margins and envelopes to be pushed to the extremes. I caution the government that they keep a very close eye on that.

The second purpose of the bill relates to the power of nominated members of the Adminis trative Appeals Tribunal to issue warrants and it implements the recommendation of the Telecommunications Interception Policy Review. This review recommended that:

The provisions allowing interception warrants to be issued by nominated members of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal should be continued and transferred to be Administrative Review Tribunal when that body is established.

I add that that should only be on the basis of equal qualifications of the personnel available. We should also try to establish that people serving on that new body do not have any conflict of interest with the agencies which might exercise these privileges. By virtue of section 3 of the Telecommunications (Interception) and Listening Device Amendment Act 1997, the power of nominated members of the AAT to issue warrants will expire on 31 December 1999. The bill will repeal section 3 and ensure that this critical function continues to be carried out by people with the necessary independence and experience.

The issue of effective law enforcement and the protection of the right of individuals must always be balanced when considering telecommunications interception. I cannot stress that too much. The government is balancing these views. While the bill widens the powers of interception, it is within fairly limited parameters. The amendments will strengthen the ability of Australian law enforcement agencies to fight a more sophisticated mode of crime.

talk.start.para: —We have heard already that the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill 1999 deals with phone tapping and powers for the Queensland Crime Commission and the Anti-Corruption Commission of Western Australia. As a Queenslander, I am naturally interested in the activities of the Queensland Crime Commission.

speech.para: I am a tremendous supporter of the Queensland Crime Commission. I believe it is a positive crime fighting force. It was established by the former coalition government in Queensland, which wrote to the federal government seeking telephone tapping powers for the activities of the QCC. The Attorney-General wrote back and he set out very well the circumstances under which this bill has been drawn up. He said:

I have considered the request on its merits and in the light of the Crime Commission Act 1997 (Qld) which I note confers extensive powers on the Commission but also imposes stringent accountability measures and close supervision by independent authorities. On that basis, I would endorse in principle amendments of the Act to confer `eligible authority' status on the Commission. If such amendments were to be passed by Parliament, this status would enable the Commission to receive lawfully intercepted information collected by other agencies which appears to be relevant to the Commission's functions. However, the Commission will not be able to seek and execute interception warrants in its own name until I—
that is, the federal Attorney-General—

exercise my discretion to make a declaration under section 34 of the Act. I cannot do that until Queensland has laws in place which comply with the requirements of section 35 of the Act. I understand that a Bill was introduced in the Queensland Parliament to create such laws but that it was not passed before the election—
that is, the 1998 election—
was called.

Currently every state police force is deemed to be an eligible authority, but not every force and not every crime fighting body has those sorts of telephone interception powers. The agencies able to apply for warrants to intercept telephone calls are the Australian Federal Police, the National Crime Authority, the Victorian police, the New South Wales Police, the New South Wales Crime Commission, the Independent Commission Against Corruption—ICAC—the South Australian police, the Western Australian police and the Police Integrity Commission of New South Wales.

It is opportune to consider this bill today, and the fact is that phone tapping powers in Queensland were first sought by the Criminal Justice Commission in 1995. In the past week or so, the Parliamentary Criminal Justice Committee in Queensland has again been considering the issue. I would like to refer to a couple of press releases that cover that time and the reports of what that committee has had to say. The Australian Associated Press of 1 October said:
A Queensland parliamentary committee will hold public hearings into whether the Criminal Justice Commission . . . and other agencies should have phone-tapping powers.
Mr Lucas—
the Parliamentary CJC chairman—
said it was envisaged organisations to make representations would include the CJC, the Queensland Crime Commission, the National Crime Authority and the Queensland Council for Civil Liberties.
A further press report on the matter dated 5 October stated:
Criminal investigation phone tapping should go ahead in Queensland but only if "rigorous" safeguards were put in place, an inquiry in Brisbane told today.
This submission to the inquiry came from the CJC, and the report goes on to state:
Two years ago, the role of the Public Interest Monitor . . . was introduced to oversee phone tapping.

Current PIM Richard Perry told the inquiry today the practice was warranted, especially when law enforcement agencies such as the CJC and police were investigating serious crimes such as murder, rape and paedophilia.
But Mr Perry said "an extremely rigorous regime" was needed to oversee such powers and ensure they were not abused.

Earlier, Council for Civil Liberties spokesman Terry O'Gorman said Queensland police already were using phone and e-mail tapping through joint operations with the National Crime Authority and Australian Federal Police.

We should have a look at the history of this particular issue, where phone tapping has come from and under what circumstances. The Commonwealth first exercised its power to make laws regulating the interception of telecommunications by enacting the Telephonic Communications (Interception) Act 1960. Under that act, it was an offence to intercept telephonic communications except in two circumstances—firstly, where interception was effected by officers of what was then the PMG department generally for technical reasons or, secondly, where interception was authorised by a warrant issued under the act. Such a warrant could only be issued to ASIO for national security purposes.

The current act specifies the circumstances in which it is lawful for an interception to take place: namely, in connection with the operation or maintenance of the telecommuni cations system or, under the authority of a warrant, the investigation by law enforcement agencies of serious offences or by ASIO for national security purposes. The amendments that we are dealing with here are basically dealing with those police enforcement provisions. I should look at what particular items come within the gamut of those law enforcement agencies when they apply for a warrant to proceed in this manner. The member for Barton made some comments in this regard, and I would just like to rehash some of the statements that were made by him and the member for Hinkler.

A class 1 offence includes murder, kidnapping and equivalent offences, certain narcotics offences and offences in relation to which the National Crime Authority is conducting a special investigation. Class 2 is defined under section 5D of the act and covers several categories of offences—serious offences involving loss of life or serious personal injury, or serious risk of loss or injury, serious damage to property in circumstances endangering a person's safety, trafficking in prescribed substances, serious fraud, serious loss to the revenue of the Commonwealth or a state or the Australian Capital Territory and bribery or corruption of or by an officer of the Commonwealth, state or territory.

When the member for Barton was talking about his concerns about MPs' phones being tapped, I think he has to bear in mind that that is one of the class 2 offences that is referred to here—`bribery or corruption of or by an officer of the Commonwealth, state or territory'. As has been found many times before, MPs, while we have an important job to do, are not above the law, and if we were, for example, to indulge in any of those low practices of bribery or corruption then certainly the law, as it provides for such offences, should come down upon us. I think it should be brought to the notice of the member for Barton that that is part of the class 2 offences. Class 2 offences also involve planning and organisation offences, money laundering offences and computer related offences.

When issuing a warrant to one of these bodies, the judge has to give consideration to various issues, and we have heard that the AAT could also be involved here. The principal matters which the judge or nominated AAT member is required to consider are: the availability of alternative methods of investigating the offence; and, in the case of class 2 offences, the gravity of the conduct being investigated and the degree of interference with the privacy of any person. Where an application for a warrant includes a request that the warrant authorise entry on premises, the judge or nominated AAT member is also required to be satisfied that it would be impractical or inappropriate to intercept communications by less intrusive means.

We should now look at what kind of impact this has had. If we look at the number of arrests that have been made by bodies utilising powers under these provisions of this particular act, we will see that, in 1995-96, 657 arrests were made, including 269 by Victoria Police. In 1997-98, 625 arrests were made, including 164 by the New South Wales police and 124 by Victoria Police. If we look at the Australian Federal Police, just one of the police bodies involved, and the range of offences being dealt with, we will see that they picked up two prosecutions in relation to murder charges, 39 in relation to narcotics charges and 20 in relation to trafficking in drugs out of a total of 97 AFP prosecutions in one particular year.

Since 1987 state governments have been able to enact legislation enabling state police services and other relevant bodies to obtain warrants to tap phones. This was investigated by the Criminal Justice Commission in Queensland through a report into telephone interception and criminal activity in Queensland. Let us look at some of the things that were covered in that report. The report harked back to September 1991 when the commission—that is, the CJC—and the Office of the Minister for Police and Emergency Services released an issues paper on the matter of investigating police powers. One matter canvassed in this paper was whether the Queensland Police Service should be given a power to tap telephones.

The commission subsequently received a number of submissions which included at least some discussion on the issue. The Queensland Police Service, for example, argued strongly that it should have the power to intercept telecommunications in order to effectively discharge its law enforcement role. The Queensland Council for Civil Liberties argued that the extent of telephone interception throughout Australia should be considered before any further extensions of power are granted. Other submissions at that time stated, for example, that the QPS, the Queensland Police Service, should seek the assistance of Commonwealth law enforcement agencies if it needed to intercept telephones, rather than having powers of its own. The CJC, having gone through all those items, concluded:
The Queensland government takes the necessary steps to enable the QPS and the Commission—
the Criminal Justice Commission—
to intercept telecommunications as they pass over the telecommunications system. This will require:
. the introduction of a State Telecommunications (Interception) Act which conforms with the requirements of the Commonwealth Act
. a request by the Premier to the Commonwealth Attorney-General to have the QPS and the Commission declared `agencies' for the purposes of the Commonwealth Act.

Now the Queensland Crime Commission is making application for these powers. What is the Queensland Crime Commission? The Queensland Crime Commission has a mandate to investigate criminal activity referred to it and, in particular, criminal paedophilia and major and organised crime. The QCC is intended to be a tightly structured, specially focused and relatively small body that can concentrate its crime fighting efforts on referred matters without the pressure of having to deal with wider policing and criminal justice issues. It intends taking a leading tactical role in the fight against organised and major criminal activity and paedophilia within Queensland as well as performing distinctly strategic intelligence gathering purposes.

The creation and continued operation of the QCC are justified only to the extent that it succeeds in areas where other investigative agencies or methods have already tried and failed or are unlikely to succeed. The QCC has a management committee, and its role is to refer matters to the QCC under special circumstances where it is satisfied that investigations using ordinary police powers would not have been effective. The Police Commissioner also can ask the committee to refer relevant criminal activity or a major crime to the QCC for investigation, but he must show that an investigation carried out by the Police Service into the matter has not been effective, that further investigation by the Police Service is unlikely to be any more effective, and that investigation by the QCC is in the public interest. The QCC's jurisdiction in relation to criminal paedophilia is also extraterritorial—that is, it extends beyond Queensland—provided that there is a connection between the offender or the victim with the state of Queensland.

The QCC has statutory power to require specified information to be provided or particular documents or things to be produced. It also has the capacity to do all other things necessary or convenient to perform its statutory functions. An authorised QCC officer may apply to a magistrate or a judge for a warrant to search private places, vehicles and people and, in cases of evident necessity, enter a place without a warrant in order to preserve evidence. With the Crime Commissioner's approval, a QCC officer can also apply for a warrant to use a tracking device or use a surveillance device without a warrant in certain circumstances. A QCC officer can apply to a Supreme Court judge for a covert search warrant or an arrest warrant. The Queensland Crime Commissioner is personally authorised to give a notice to produce to a person requiring the production of a specified document or thing and he can also issue a written attendance notice requiring a person to attend a QCC hearing. Finally, all QCC officers are entitled to seize anything found in a place lawfully entered that provides evidence in connection with a QCC investigation.
So what has the QCC achieved so far? A 12 November 1998 report of the Australian Associated Press on the annual report of the QCC states:
The QCC annual report showed in its first 10 months, the body set up to investigate paedophilia and organised crime had assisted police in laying 65 criminal charges.
The report further states:
. . . the QCC has launched two major investigations in partnership with police—Project Axis and Project Krystal.
Project Axis aims to reduce the number of serial or systematic sex offences against children.
Project Krystal aims to assess the level of organised crime in Queensland.

In that period—the first seven months of the operation of the QCC—there had already been a total of six arrests. The QCC is structured in such a way to ensure that it represents a wide range of law enforcement interests in the state. It has a management committee. The members of that management committee are the Crime Commissioner, the Police Commissioner of Queensland, the Chairperson of the Criminal Justice Commission, the Chairperson of the National Crime Authority, the Chairperson and Deputy Chairperson of the Parliamentary Criminal Justice Committee, the Children's Commissioner, and two community representatives—of which one must be a woman and the other must have an interest in civil liberties. In that latter category, Sherree Meyer of the Queensland Homicide Victims Support Group is included. That run-down of the make-up of that body shows what authoritative checks and balances apply to the Queensland Crime Commission.

Unlike the sometimes controversial other organisation—the Queensland Criminal Justice Commission—the QCC has shown an ability to get on with its activities in a comparatively low profile manner, as befits such a body. The Commissioner of the QCC is a distinguished crime fighter in Queensland, Tim Carmody. I pause to refer to some of his achievements. He is a former police officer who was admitted to the Queensland Bar in 1982 and specialised in major criminal trial and appeal work. He was also counsel assisting the Connolly Ryan inquiry into the future of the CJC. Those are a couple of the major highlights of his career. The important fact is that he has strong political support from both sides of politics in Queensland, and in a community sense he really is a straight shooter.

In looking at what Commissioner Carmody has to say about issues such as the utilisation of phone tapping powers, I refer to an article recently in the Courier-Mail in Brisbane where he was reported as saying that the body had focused its operational efforts on seven investigative leads and two major projects. I referred before to Project Axis, which had been established with the Queensland police force to minimise the commission of serial and systematic sex offences against children. The range of issues that Project Axis and Project Krystal have investigated cover a wide range of the criminal landscape in Queensland. The Courier-Mail article states that Mr Carmody, in the QCC annual report, questioned the cost of crime, arguing for the introduction of legislation allowing the Queensland Crime Commission to recover its operational costs by using the proceeds of crime. I think that is something that Queenslanders and Australians in general would like to see a lot more of.

The Queensland Crime Commission operate with a staffing level of 37 at the current time. In 1998 and 1999, they rounded up a total of 47 offenders, laying 292 charges. They have a budget of $4.3 million for 1999-2000, with $3.3 million going into combating major crime and paedophilia and another $622,000 going into the maintenance of an effective intelligence service. Recently the Queensland Crime Commission released a report on Project Krystal, which was referred to in the Courier-Mail in an article by Wayne Smith. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —in reply—I thank the members for Barton, Hinkler and Blair, who have contributed to the debate on the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill 1999 , and I thank the opposition for their support of the bill. It is right that members who deal with a subject like telecommunications interception should express grave reservations about the use of this intrusive power. I know that I have done the same in the past on debates when speaking in opposition. It is very important that the government takes a very responsible attitude towards the granting of powers to intercept telecommunications covertly, even though the purpose for which the interceptions may be made—protection of the community from crime and from things like terrorism and politically motivated violence—are of themselves grave issues.

speech.para: The member for Barton has raised the question of why judges should not continue to perform the function. I think he probably understands reasonably well what the reasoning is, but for the record let me explain. I, too, shared the reservations that the member for Barton had in relation to judges ceasing to be the issuing authorities and it being necessary to find another body of persons capable of doing it. But there is a good reason. The function is currently performed by consenting judges of the Federal Court and the Family Court. The amendments that were made in 1997 were necessary because the Federal Court judges have generally stated that they believe this is a function they should no longer perform and that they should withdraw their consent. The Family Court has made a similar indication.

In the case of the Family Court, this was prompted by two factors, one being that a number of the judges of the Federal Court were the respondents to applications for judicial review of the decision to issue a warrant. Those applications were made in the very court in which the issuing judges sat. Another reason related to a decision of the High Court in Grollo v. Palmer in 1995. The court held that the provisions of the Telecommunications (Interception) Act conferring the power to issue interception warrants on eligible judges are valid, as the act confers the function on judges not as judges but as personae designatae and not on the courts of which they are members.

However, the court also stated that the power to confer non-judicial functions on judges as designated persons was subject to two conditions. Firstly, the individual judge must consent to the conferral and, secondly, a non-judicial function cannot be conferred if it is incompatible with either the performance of judges' judicial duties or the integrity of the judiciary. We understand that judges are concerned that the workload associated with issuing warrants is interfering with their judicial duties. It can take one or two hours of a judge's time to consider a single application for an interception warrant.

The judges have also noted that, in the Grollo case, the High Court accepted as `troubling' arguments that the involvement of judges in the process of issuing warrants may give rise to an apprehension of bias. More recent decisions of the High Court—among them Wilson v. the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs—have stressed concerns that the legitimacy and independence of the judiciary must not be compromised by appointing judges to perform non-judicial functions. In the Grollo case, the High Court specifically advised the judges of the ACT Supreme Court not to accept an appointment as an eligible judge because of the possibility that a judge who issues a warrant may be involved in a related criminal proceeding. Both judges in the situation subsequently withdrew their consent.

Given the concerns of federal judges about the compatibility of this function with judicial duties, it would not be appropriate to seek to confer the function on judges of state courts. The same constitutional limitations apply to the federal parliament imposing administrative functions on state judges. Authorities for this proposition are Kable v. DPP in 1996 and the Queen Victoria Memorial Hospital v. Thornton in 1953. The concerns of the High Court about the ACT Supreme Court also apply to state Supreme Court judges who are involved in day-to-day criminal proceedings.

The Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979 sets out in some detail the matters about which an eligible judge or nominated member of the AAT must be satisfied before issuing an interception warrant. These provisions are to ensure that the person issuing the warrant fairly weighs up the competing considerations of privacy and private property on the one hand and law enforcement on the other. The Australian Federal Police Act and the Customs Act also set out requirements for the issue of listening device warrants. These requirements are unaffected by the amendments. The Telecommunications (Interception) Act requires a judge or nominated AAT member to consider certain issues before issuing the warrant. Those issues include that the person is likely to use the service, that the information is not available by other means, that the offence is serious and that the act itself places appropriate safeguards on the action of interception.

The Telecommunications Interception Policy Review found that nominated members of the AAT have a high status and are independent of the executive. The review found that they bring to their task a seriousness of purpose and a commitment to the principles of accountability which serve the public well. Only persons expressly nominated by the minister are authorised to issue warrants. The nomination process includes consultation with the President of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal concerning the suitability of individual members to be nominated. The High Court has itself indicated that, in addition to judges, many other persons and tribunals are also well fitted to issue these warrants.

The Telecommunications Interception Policy Review was tabled on 25 August 1999. A recommendation of the review was that the provisions allowing interception warrants to be issued by nominated members of the AAT should be continued and transferred to the ART when that body is established. The review found that the conferral of the power on nominated members of the AAT had worked well in practice. The review also found that the AAT members who have been nominated have a high status and are independent of the executive. As I said, the review found that they bring to the task a seriousness of purpose and a commitment to the principles of accountability.

The member for Barton has foreshadowed potential opposition to the transfer of the authority from members of the AAT to members of the ART—that is, the Administrative Review Tribunal, which it is proposed should be established by the combination of the AAT, the Social Security Appeals Tribunal, the Immigration Review Tribunal and the Refugee Review Tribunal. I think the member for Barton can be reassured that it is not intended in any way that the members who issue warrants would have lesser qualifications than the current members of the AAT. The Telecommunications (Interception) Act requires that the Attorney-General must not nominate a person who holds an appointment as a part-time senior member or a member of the tribunal unless the person is a legal practitioner of at least five years experience. This requirement will be retained regardless of the form of the ART legislation. Therefore, members who issue warrants will be equally suitably qualified to consider complex legal issues as those who currently issue them.

A question has been raised about the level of offence in respect of which telecommunications interception warrants can be issued. It is plain under the existing legislation that a warrant cannot be used for trivial matters. The act defines serious offences by reference to the penalty attached. An offence must be punishable by at least seven years imprisonment. Because the Telecommunications (Interception) Act covers several jurisdictions—and we are adding at least one new jurisdiction under this bill—the definitions have to be general.

The issue of the exchange of intercepted information between agencies was also raised. In response to that expression of concern, I remind members that section 68 of the Telecommunications (Interception) Act also specifies circumstances where information may be exchanged. It can be done only under the control and responsibility of the chief officer of the communicating agency. It may be communicated only where the offence is punishable by at least three years imprisonment or is a police disciplinary matter or a public service disciplinary matter. When the receiving agency receives the intercepted information, it is subject to all the stringent controls found in part VII of the act which regulate the original acquisition of the information.

The member for Barton also raised the possibility of a national oversight committee to coordinate the activities of the various Commonwealth and state inspecting authorities, who are principally ombudsmen, and to develop a national code of best practice. The state inspecting authorities actually report through state ministers to the Commonwealth minister on the annual outcomes of their inspections, and then the Commonwealth Ombudsman reports directly to the Commonwealth minister. In these circumstances, I would suggest there is no need for the formation of a national oversight committee since the function the member for Barton contemplates might be performed is in fact already being performed.

This bill is a significant bill, and it is right that members should carefully consider it. It is important for law enforcement in Australia. As criminal activity in this country becomes more sophisticated, our law enforcement agencies should be equipped with the most effective investigative tools available. Telecommunications interception provides law enforcement agencies with a proven cost-effective technique for uncovering and prosecuting serious organised crime and serious corruption.

The bill will give the Anti-Corruption Commission of Western Australia and the Crime Commission of Queensland the means to perform their crucial functions more effectively. The government is aware of the corrosive effect unchallenged organised crime and corruption can have on our society. For this reason, the Commonwealth supports the government of Queensland in its moves to deal with paedophilia and organised crime and the government of Western Australia in its efforts to excise corruption, crime and serious improper conduct of public officers by providing the respective commissions with appropriate and effective investigative powers but subject to the existing stringent safeguards in the interception act. These powers will, however, be ineffective if there is no independent authority available to issue warrants authorising their use.

The Telecommunications Interception Policy Review found that the practice of nominated members of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal issuing warrants has worked well. The nominated AAT members bring to their task a seriousness of purpose and a commitment to appropriate principles of accountability, and the public interest is accordingly served. The government believes the AAT members have demonstrated independence, experience and expertise in their role. On that basis, the nominated members of the AAT should be able to continue to issue interception warrants.

The bill reflects the government's commitment to providing effective tools for law enforcement while ensuring the appropriate safeguards are in place to protect individual rights. I commend the bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

subdebate.1.para: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Williams) read a third time.

debateinfo.title: DIESEL AND ALTERNATIVE FUELS GRANTS SCHEME (ADMINISTRATION AND COMPLIANCE) BILL 1999

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 23 September, on motion by Mr Hockey:
That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme (Administration and Compliance) Bill 1999 is another botched implementation measure of the GST deal. It is a fascinating piece of legislation as well, because it introduces the notion of conurbations but does not define them, it extends the nightmare on main street that was the GST to a nightmare on highway 1 and it introduces dipsticks as the armoury of the diesel fuel police in ensuring that this measure can be carried out.

speech.para: The exercise that preceded the Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme (Administration and Compliance) Bill 1999 debate was a shameful one. The National Party first of all deceived the bush and then capitulated to the Liberal Party. Then the Democrats capitulated to the Prime Minister, who then dudded the National Party. It was a nice little three-way double deal. As Peter Garrett said, it was a dirty deal done dirt cheap. The then leader of the National Party, Mr Fischer, originally said that he would support a GST only if fuel excise were abolished. But he reneged on that pledge, as the fuel credit scheme that was announced by the government in fact retained fuel excise. This meant no reduction in petrol tax for ordinary motorists and an increase in the city-country price differential—a bad deal for country Australia. But that is only the beginning of it.

The government promised a whole package of measures on diesel which it has reneged on. This House recently dealt with legislation where the government was trying to renege on a deal cut with the Democrats to get the GST through. The Prime Minister used the diesel fuel rebate in the forestry industry as a bargaining chip in order to fool the Democrats. He promised to cut the diesel fuel rebate to foresters to secure Democrat support for the GST, and now he has reneged on that deal. This legislation is one more step in the government ratting on the promises it made to the road transport industry.

The former Leader of the National Party promised that he would resign if he did not deliver the full diesel promise. The deal done with the Democrats ensured that he did not deliver on that promise. He has since resigned for different reasons, but the truth is that, if he were true to his word, he should have done it anyway. The current Leader of the National Party also promised that he would resign if the deal was not delivered. He has not resigned, but he has reneged on the deal as well. This Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grant Scheme came about because the deal with the Democrats was unconstitutional. The deal was so bad that it was against the Constitution—it was against the Constitution to divide the nation into city and country regions and to impose differential tax regimes. That is how the government originally wanted to do it, but they could not.

So we are left with this uncertainty surrounding the grant scheme. The government could not do what they wanted to do through the tax mechanism because of the differentiation between rural and city, so they came up with this scheme. It is the second piece of legislation concerning the diesel grant scheme. The first piece was introduced at 9.30 one night and debated at 9.30 the following morning. That in itself was an absolute disgrace because Labor and the public should have been entitled to have the opportunity to dissect that bill and fully understand it before it was dealt with in the House. Because of the confusion surrounding the scheme, the government could not give us details on it at the time. This is what happens when you rush things through—when you rush through what has been a deal done on the run to secure a GST at any cost.

We remember Tim Fischer, the then Leader of the National Party and Deputy Prime Minister, saying to us, when we asked about the further detail, `Wait, it is all going to be explained in the explanatory memorandum.' He said that everything would be revealed therein. We waited for the explanatory memorandum and it revealed that the government did not know what the scheme that they had agreed to was actually all about. The government wanted us to pass that legislation and then wait for months until they worked out how it was to be applied through administrative arrangements. The truth is that we have been cooperative as an opposition, and we want to try to end the confusion for the road transport industry. On that basis, we reluctantly agreed to that approach, flawed as it was.

Tonight we have before us the next piece of legislation, which is supposed to deal with these administrative issues—the issues that they said would be cleared up later. But what do we find? We find that this legislation still does not end the confusion. Rather, it defers yet again the issue of the boundaries between the city and the country—the so-called urban conurbation boundary lines. The definition of those boundaries is critical because journeys by vehicles, by trucks, wholly within the conurbation do not get the grant—they do not get the concession that now has to be given in a grant form. If they cross any part of the conurbation, they can qualify for the whole of the grant. If you understand that point, you understand that the definition of the conurbation is actually critical. Without it, the scheme is meaningless. Yet now the second piece of legislation is before us and we still do not have the definition of those boundaries. What incompetence—deals done on the run and still total uncertainty.

Apart from the difficulty in the definition—which we say is critical and which we say, without it, is a meaningless proposal—it gets worse because the new scheme imposes a huge new compliance burden on transport operators. It involves more paperwork, more record keeping requirements, more expense in seeking professional advisers to navigate through the red tape and the potential for penalties if people make mistakes. So not only do the small transport businesses have to contend with the GST compliance nightmare and all of the compliance burden that that entails—which the Treasurer himself coined as the nightmare on main street—but these businesses get the double whammy because they get the next instalment: a nightmare on highway 1.

Since June, Labor has been asking: what are the areas that qualify for the grant and what are the areas that do not? We have had many examples raised in this House—questions about where people can locate their transport operations to take advantage of the scheme by operating just outside of the conurbation and coming into the capital city. We are constantly told that it will be explained soon. However, each time that has occurred, we find nothing but continued silence and a continued inability to answer from the government.

Transport operators have the right to be able to plan their businesses with certainty. This government is not giving them that certainty. They have a right to expect that governments set out the rules simply and with adequate time to prepare for them. It is now more than four months since the dirty deal was struck with the Democrats, yet we still do not have the detail of the scheme—even though it is a scheme that the government has costed down to the last million dollars. How can the government do that, unless it has an idea of what these boundaries are?

Either the government know exactly where the boundaries are between those that get the grant and those that are discriminated against and they are not going to tell anyone, or they still do not have any idea of what they have agreed with the Democrats and they have just made up the figures. Either they are hiding the truth from the Australian people because they are worried about what a nightmare they are going to impose on the transport industry or they have no idea, in which case how can they seriously depend upon the rigour of the figures associated with the Prime Minister's press release? It is for these reasons that I move the second reading amendment which has been circulated in my name:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for:

(1) continuing the uncertainty in the transport industry by not releasing the details of the boundaries of urban conurbations for the purposes of the Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme (the Scheme);
(2) not disclosing, prior to the last election, the new powers being proposed for the Commissioner of Taxation to stop, detain and search vehicles;
(3) imposing a complex new layer of administration on transport operators in connection with the Scheme, in addition to the new compliance burden associated with the Goods and Services Tax; and
(4) its failure to disclose the basis of its claims that the programs agreed with the Democrats will counter the greenhouse gas increasing effects of the Scheme."

Since June, in this House, we have asked repeated questions about how the nightmare will work. We never get any answers. All of the transport operators who live and work around urban centres have a right to know whether they will qualify, yet they are being kept in the dark. There is important new information in this bill but, as usual, there are more questions posed than answered.

There are the record keeping requirements, for example. These impose the new red tape for the grants. If you fail to satisfy the provisions of clause 18, you do not qualify for any grant. We now know that, but what we do not know is what you have to do to satisfy the clause. As usual, in this legislation the detail is not specified but is deferred to a determination not yet issued by the tax commissioner. So we do not know what the record keeping requirements are in order for people to qualify for the grants. On top of that, we still do not know which journeys will qualify for the grant.

But there are new provisions which are complete. These are the new powers of the diesel police. These are the new powers that transport operators will now face. This bill allows virtually unlimited access to premises. It creates an offence if people do not comply exactly. But that is not all. This bill also creates new powers for the tax commissioner to stop vehicles and to search them. So this is legislation that sets up the diesel police.

First of all, we have the GST police. They are armed with the thermometers, going around the food stalls determining, when food goes from hot to cold, whether or not the GST applies. Now we are equipping the diesel police with the dipstick. There they will be, out on the pillbox on the border of the conurbation, dipstick in pocket, stopping the vehicle, sticking in this dipstick to work out how much the vehicle has used coming across the border. Not only will they have dipsticks but they will have the power to search and seize. You would have to be a dipstick to introduce this proposal—that is the truth of it. This is absolute madness. This is what happens when you cobble together something on the run.

Truck drivers in Australia will now face unprecedented intrusion in their businesses—indeed, in their personal affairs. You can just imagine the truck driver who has been on a long haul. He arrives home later than normal. The wife is at the door. `Hello, dear. Why are you so late?' He says, `The tax commissioner was there on the highway. He jumped out of the pillbox and ordered my truck to be stopped and searched. I've just experienced the nightmare on highway 1—one of many. For the last few hours, they've tried hard to work out what needs to be done. This is what Labor warned would happen and the government said wouldn't.' The wife then looks behind him and says, `You've brought someone home for dinner.' He says, `Well, not exactly, but since the tax commissioner believes that there are some documents here relating to the diesel grants scheme he has decided to enter the home and stay here for "a reasonable time".' The tax commissioner can do that because clause 47 of the bill enables him to. By the way, he does not just visit for a reasonable time. According to clause 47(2)(d), he has a right to inspect, examine, count, measure, weigh, gauge, test or analyse any such goods or other property on those premises to that end and, to that end, take samples.

What a lovely little piece of administration this is. This is all about putting the diesel dipstick into place. We have got such a complicated system that, firstly, we do not know what the boundaries are and, secondly, we have the diesel police not just with the dipstick but with a search warrant going in and occupying the house and undertaking all of this investigation. But don't worry about that, this is all part of this brave new world the Treasurer has talked about—you do not have to cook him dinner; you just let him run through the house and check and assess what he wants. The government is providing itself with all these new powers. It is imposing new requirements on transport operators, but it has not addressed any of the confusion it has caused with the deal done with the Democrats.

Why did the Democrats insist upon this as part of the overall dirty deal? They claim that their motivation was the environment. Let us have a brief look at the achievement on that. In essence, we had the Treasurer admitting that this was done because the Democrats:

. . . wanted to keep fumes and emissions down in capital cities, large cities and large conurbations. That is the agreement that we have reached to protect rural and regional Australia, help the trucking industry and reduce diesel excise.
That is what he said on 31 May when he was explaining this deal in amongst the thermometers in chooks, the packets of salad and all of the other crazy things that came out of this deal.

But, if that is what the Democrats sought to achieve, did they? They had an expert adviser, a Dr Clive Hamilton, from the Australia Institute advising them on this and other environmental issues. He was their expert to help them through their considerations, their negotiations, their deliberations with the government on the GST. What did he do? He examined what the government was offering the Democrats—this incomplete legislation we now have before the House—and advised them against it because it was a nonsense proposal in terms of protecting the environment and then he resigned when he saw that the Democrats were committed to it.

Dr Hamilton is a man of integrity and he refused to be associated with this dud deal. He knew that the Democrats were getting conned by the government, and he tried to warn them. But they did not listen. They did not care. They were going to shaft the community with the GST and shaft the urban environment as well. Their theory was: don't give the subsidy in the city because it will encourage diesel and air pollution. You might say on the face of it that is a worthy objective, but under the scheme the operator can still get it in the city so long as they travel outside the conurbation. No wonder Dr Hamilton resigned. These are dills who negotiated this deal, either unwittingly or prepared to be conned.

The fact that the truck operators would also face an administrative nightmare did not worry the Democrats either. So they did not succeed in their objective, which was supposed to be environmentally driven. In the process, they have imposed an administrative and compliance nightmare on diesel truck operators operating in the transport industry on top of the compliance nightmare that they have given them with the GST and the deal done on the GST. They were naive and they were gullible, but this is just the sort of people that the Prime Minister likes to prey on, and we have seen many examples of that.

But the truth of it is that the Australian transport industry is now having to bear the cost of these compromises. It is the industry that is going to have to deal with these nightmares, this confusion and this intrusion. As well as copping the paperwork and uncertainty, they now face unprecedented government powers. This is not what they expected when the government told them that they were going to introduce this brave new taxation world. They were told that this would be a simpler system. They were told that this would be a system that would give them benefits. This is not a simpler system and this does not give them benefits. The qualification in terms of the grant involves significant paperwork, significant policing and uncertainty about the boundaries in which they can qualify.

It is against that background that I have moved the second reading amendment. We believe that this is another example which highlights the haste that was undertaken in trying to implement and secure this deal. There are many of those examples, and we have used the House each time we have had the legislation before us. There have already been significant amendments to the original GST bills, and there are more to come. And there will continue to be more to come. This is not a simpler system. This bill before us today indicates the complexity that is going to be associated with this new tax regime.

This is something that the transport operators are going to have to come to grips with between now and when it is implemented in the middle of next year, but it is something they have not been given any assistance, any encouragement and any clarification on by the government. We will continue to expose the deficiencies in the government's legislation. We will continue to use the forms of the House to try to ensure that these problems do in some way get mitigated, but the fundamental point is that this is a bad deal for the transport industry, just as the GST was a bad deal for the Australian public.

We will have many more opportunities to highlight the deficiencies, but the Australian public should be very wary of what is in store for them. At the moment the government believe this is off the agenda—that they have got the deal through, it has been passed and legislation is coming forward and people will be happy as it gets implemented. They will not be happy with the implementation, because once they understand what it involves, how it impacts upon them and how it adversely impacts upon them they will have a very different view to the government's of the benefits of this legislation.

talk.start.para: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak at a later time.

—Australians certainly will be pleased when the Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme (Administration and Compliance) Bill 1999 comes into action next year. This is a far-sighted meeting of Australia's vital needs in the expensive transportation of our goods around the nation. Australia is two to three times more reliant on its road transport systems than any other equivalent nation. In fact, information that has been given to me indicates that the trucking industry slogan of `Carrying the Nation' is not far wrong, and Australia has a dependency on road transport which is three times the OECD average. So everything that is done within this nation—from our great farming enterprises to our factories, even to the point of transporting our goods by sea to their ports of destination—is affected by fuels, and mainly diesel fuels.

speech.para: This legislation that the House is debating tonight is something that should have been introduced into Australia many years ago. The Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grant Scheme is a program which covers not only diesel fuel but other fuels as well, such as compressed natural gas, liquefied petroleum gas, recycled waste oil, ethanol, canola oil and other prescribed fuels. These fuels are all prescribed in the act as a way of reducing costs and making our nation more efficient in what we do.

The advantages of reducing the price of fuels—because that, in fact, is what this legislation does—apply to rail as much as to road. Whilst the opposition would want to muddy the waters and make it appear that this is a difficult to administer piece of legislation and that there will be chaos in the streets, what they will find as it comes into action is that for the majority of those in the transport industry it will be quite simple. Far from being a heavy-handed process of surveillance and supervision, this is nothing more than what goes on now with checking weights and lengths of road transport units—something that is done every day in every state of Australia.

I want to commend the government for coming forward with a program that will make massive differences to costs, which will have the effect of bringing the nation closer together so that the competitive force that we need to exert against those in whose markets we compete is not damaged by the incredible distances that Australian producers have to face—distances not only from farm or factory to waterside but from wharf to ultimate destination.

The legislation is simple because the grants scheme applies to vehicles with a gross mass of 20 tonnes or more and will require little record keeping of kilometres travelled, litres used and receipts. So we remove with one swift swipe all of those vehicles with a gross mass of 20 tonnes or more. Eligible fuel used in vehicles between 4.5 and 20 tonnes outside the metropolitan area will not have complicated record keeping processes either. So the narrow area where there is complexity to some degree is for those vehicles which have a mass of 4.5 to 20 tonnes which operate in and outside metropolitan areas. Extensive records will be required for those vehicles. There is no doubt about that. It is not the government's wish or the government's intention. The member for Dickson may well smile. She might have been part of the process if she had not been here. The fact of the matter is that for that narrow area there is increased complexity, and more extensive record keeping will be required.

The scheme applies not only to the movement of freight and goods—the products of our farms and factories—but also to the movement of people. The Bus and Coach Association have committed themselves tonight to an extensive program of cooperating with the greenhouse challenge that confronts Australia and the commitments that the Australian government has made. They happen to be here this night for this very important occasion. But every bus and coach operating in an urban area will also, if they are between that 4.5 and 20 tonnes in weight, have the complexity of record keeping and a disadvantage compared with fleet or motor vehicle owners.

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 6.30 p.m. to 8.00 p.m.

talk.start.para: —The House is debating tonight the Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme (Administration and Compli ance) Bill 1999 . It is a bill with a long title but it is a simple bill. It really just proposes that the Australian road and rail transport industries are actually able to compete on a better level than ever before. That has been the role of the Howard government and of the coalition ministers who have understood the needs of our great nation, which is reliant—to an extent perhaps three times greater than any other nation on earth—on a road and rail based transport industry. There is no OECD country more dependent on road transport than Australia is. In fact, Australia is three times more dependent on road and rail transport than its competitors are. Therefore, built into all of the costs of moving goods grown on farms or manufactured in factories to the waterside and then from the waterside overseas is the huge factor of road and rail transport.

speech.para: Australia suffers serious economic disadvantage and yet our fuel prices have been historically high. The average motorist in Sydney or Melbourne understands how high their fuel prices are. One only has to travel to the United States to understand that successive governments of Australia have seen an advantage in taxing highly the motorist—and not just the average private motorist but also the whole of the road transport industry. The argument has run that governments need a resource to put back into the road system and to build up the road system. The fact is—as you know, Mr Deputy Speaker Causley, coming from rural Australia—that there has never been a return to the road users of all the taxes they have paid.

Although we have an excellent program of increasing expenditure on roads, the government has not chosen to use all of the taxes collected from road users to massively increase the road system. We have chosen to reduce the cost of transportation to motorists and particularly to our transport industries. That will make a massive difference to the cost of everything that we do. We hear critics of this new tax system that Australia is moving into saying, `But the cost is going to be at least 10 per cent.' The fact of the matter is that this piece of legislation dramatically reduces the costs of everything in Australia. Everything has got to go on a truck or go by rail. To reduce the cost of that process is going to affect everything we eat, everything we wear, everything we use. Everything that our society uses is going to be impacted upon by this legislation.

So the government has provided, by the Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme, a grant of $600 million in 2000-01 and, in the financial year 2001-02, one of $690 million. That is restricted to use by 20-tonne-mass trucks outside metropolitan areas. The advantage is restricted to those trucks in the range of four to 20 tonnes which move in and out of metropolitan areas and it is restricted to those trucks which are 20 tonnes or more in mass moving in metropolitan areas. So what misses out? The lighter vehicles moving in metropolitan areas. This was a concession that the government gave to the Australian Democrats in order to see the passage of this legislation. So the advantage is there for the real economic earners of Australia, but there is a complicating factor of compliance which has been imposed by the restrictions—something that the government would have preferred not to have had but which is there.

This bill means that a person must be registered before they can become eligible to receive this grant, and so there is a registration process and a definition process of what comprises a journey—whether a journey includes metropolitan and non-metropolitan travel. The Commissioner for Taxation needs to determine what exactly a journey is. In so doing, he must consult the transport industry, the Bus Industry Confederation, the Australian Trucking Association, the National Farmers Federation and any other organisations specified in the regulations yet to be drafted. So the commissioner determines with the industry what a trip is. People are registered and then it is decided what trips are. Record keeping requirements are necessary. Minimal recordkeeping requirements are there for those trucks of 20 tonnes mass and over, and very few for those of four to 20 tonnes outside the metropolitan area; but there are substantial record keeping requirements for vehicles of four to 20 tonnes within city areas. The records must substantiate the claims, of course, and they must be kept and maintained for a period of not less than five years after the claim is made, so there is a capacity to go back and identify any problem.

Why is it necessary to do this? The benefit from the reduction in fuel prices is so substantial that the temptation is there—I know it would never happen in any of the electorates of the members present here, certainly not in Deputy Speaker Causley's electorate—to play with the system and subvert funds from this diesel fuel grant. So there are strong enforcement measures in this legislation to discourage people from even being tempted to manipulate the system. If a person is caught manipulating the system, they are disqualified and pay penalties.

This fuel grant has been welcomed widely throughout Australia. When the minister, Mr Joe Hockey, announced the bill, a spokesman for the Australian Trucking Association said on 24 September that the process had been very successful—an endorsement for the process the government had adopted from the Australian Trucking Association. The trucking industry slogan says that the trucks of Australia are `Carrying the Nation'. In view of the dependency Australia has on road transport, that is not far from wrong either.
Farmers of Australia have not been slow to see the advantages of this system. The President of the New South Wales Farmers Federation, Mr John Cobb, said on 26 May 1999:
Australians are twice as dependent on road transport as comparable developed countries—distance is our most significant competitive disadvantage.

He is absolutely right. This is going to restore the balance and do something for our competitiveness. Not only will it bring local costs down; it will mean that things we export are going to be more competitively priced. Mr Cobb went on to say:

The reality is that diesel is already the fuel of the transport industry. New registrations of petrol and gas trucks are the exception, not the rule, so the opportunity for switching to diesel is limited. Blocking a cut in diesel fuel excise maintains a penalty on Australia without addressing the real problem.
The average household spends $29 a week on fuel excise—half directly at the fuel pump and the other half in higher prices.

As I have already said, every family is penalised by the regime of taxing fuels that Australia has had. The Road Transport Forum and the Australian Trucking Association must be the very heart, I would think, of private enterprise in Australia. They have claimed a 75 per cent reduction in emissions and they ask why there is so much resistance to this change in fuel use when we are starting to take charge of emissions. Mr Andrew Higginson, the executive officer of the Road Transport Forum, said:

The report shows the trucking industry is leading the way in addressing pollution and emission issues. The introduction of Euro 2 and Euro 3 emission rated engines and the lowering of sulphur content in fuel will reduce particulate emissions by 75%.

What a great record this industry has. The National Road Transport Commission has data which shows that cheaper fuels will not have a detrimental environmental effect and will not bring about an increased use of fuel. The commission said that over 90 per cent of the freight in cities is moved by road anyway, so cheaper fuel will hardly make a difference. The loads will not be carried twice. The freight will not be shifted twice—90 per cent goes by road now and that will continue to be the case. If that percentage increases at the margin, it will make only a small difference to the total use of fuels. The executive director of the Minerals Council of Australia, Dick Wells, said:
. . . while the mining industry would benefit from the diesel fuel rebate, it still paid an effective rate of 11.8 per cent wholesale sales tax on diesel—
the mining industry does that—
an impost none of Australia's major competitors faced.

We are expecting our miners to work with lead in the saddlebags. The way we have been behaving is not realistic. Ian Donges from the NFF said that during the election campaign the Prime Minister made a commitment to the nation and that during that campaign the NFF campaigned for the total removal of fuel excise and for the application of a fair road user charge. So the reduction in diesel fuel excise contained in this package that the House will pass tonight already represents a significant compromise position for the farmers—and the farmers are delighted with the result. With regard to the criticisms from the Senate, Ian Donges said:
Over the last 2 years, the pump prices of petrol and diesel have fallen dramatically.

This gives the lie to the claims of some members of the Senate and the committee that examined this issue. He said that the Senate committee's conclusions regarding the impact of diesel fuel cuts under the government's tax package are wrong and based on untested research. As I have said, Mr Donges said that over the last two years the pump prices of petrol and diesel have fallen dramatically. He went on to say:
Total national consumption of petrol products was 48,178 megalitres in 1996.
He said that consumption had decreased as fuel prices have come down. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on what I regard as being a far from simple bill. The opposition's approach to the Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme (Administration and Compliance) Bill 1999 is contrary to that of the member for Mitchell. The bill is in essence best described as seeking to implement the administration and compliance regime for the scheme. Not only do I question the member for Mitchell's claim that the bill is simple in nature; I also reject the member for Mitchell's claim that the bill—when it is in place as an act of this parliament—will not lead to an endeavour by some in the community to bypass the intent of the administrative arrangements relating to this diesel fuel rebate.

speech.para: It is for that reason—although I have had opposition responsibility for the transport portfolio for only just over a week—that I can say, contrary to what previous speakers on the government side have said, that many in the industry regard the bill as an embarrassment and a joke when it comes to the government's approach to the matters before the House today. I suppose that is a fairly harsh statement but, in many ways, it reflects comments made to me over the last couple of days by those in the industry and comments made to me at a function—which the member for Mitchell also attended—this evening by people operating in the bus industry. They said to me that the problem is that the government simply does not understand the nature of the industries that it seeks to cover with the bill, and that there is no other way to describe the bill other than as a joke and an administrative nightmare from the point of view of those people who will be expected to operate under the regime that will arise as a result of the bill.

It is hard to believe that any member of the government can come in here and speak on this legislation without feeling embarrassed by the lack of detail, by the shoddiness and the dishonesty of the process that surrounds it, and by the very obvious failure of the government, the minister for transport, and their partners in this debacle, the Democrats, to devise a workable diesel fuel rebate scheme. When the government did its deal with the Democrats back in May, the opposition's concerns—and the concerns of a number of organisations, both small and large operators in industries covered by this bill—about changes to the diesel fuel rebate scheme were brushed aside in public debate, in question time, and in debate in the House and in the Senate.

When we objected to debating legislation that contained no detail about how the scheme would work in practice, we were told by the government that the administrative and compliance arrangements needed to support the scheme would be introduced before Christmas. But anyone who thought his or her questions about this scheme would be answered `prior to Christmas', as the minister for transport kept telling us, will be sorely disappointed. Not only does the bill not answer any of those questions; it unfortunately raises further questions, which remain unanswered. It also raises further uncertainty, confusion and concern. That is why the shadow Treasurer, in speaking to the bill this evening, moved a second reading amendment that clearly places the concerns of the opposition on the table for consideration by the House and, more importantly, by those in the Australian community who will be expected to operate in an honest and efficient fashion under the terms of the bill.

Having said that, it is also fair to say that the last time these matters were debated, and questions were raised about implementation and the various administrative regimes intended by the bill, the shadow Treasurer, the member for Hotham, correctly referred to the scheme as a nightmare on highway 1. Nothing in this bill suggests that he was in any way wrong in describing this bill as a nightmare on highway 1. The most extraordinary thing about this legislation is that we still do not know how a metropolitan area is to be defined. We still do not know where the boundaries between metropolitan and non-metropolitan areas will be drawn.

I would have thought, for an operator in the industry, no matter how big or small, that that is a pretty fundamental question, a pretty fundamental gap, because the entire purpose of the scheme is to quarantine the reduction in the diesel fuel rebate to country areas. I remind the House that all vehicles over 20 tonnes are eligible for a new fuel grant, that vehicles under 4.5 tonnes are ineligible and that vehicles between 4.5 and 20 tonnes are only eligible for that part of their journey that is in a non-metropolitan zone. Simple, the member for Mitchell suggests—well, it is not simple to the operators in the industry, including some that live and operate in his electorate. I suggest that he, with other members of the government, ought to come clean and put on the table for proper debate, and for public consumption and consideration, answers to the questions we have posed during this debate.

On that matter, I also believe the government and the Democrats told us back in June that the grant would not apply in metropolitan areas surrounding capital cities—other than Darwin and Hobart; in the conurbation running from the Queensland Sunshine Coast to New South Wales; in Geelong; and in the conurbation running from Newcastle to Wollongong. At the time we asked: where do you draw the boundaries? How do you define a journey? How much record keeping will be required and how are you going to police this? These are pretty straightforward questions, I would have thought. They are questions that surely the government and their partners in crime, the Democrats, would have considered when agreeing upon the proposition before the House this evening. Rather, they have placed before the House the nightmare, the mess, that we currently have to consider and debate—according to our best endeavours and in, I dare say, a constructive way.

When we asked those questions the answer was—and it is also the answer today—`all will be revealed prior to Christmas.' It is almost as if the minister for transport, as he runs around Red Hill—or is it Snob Hill in Canberra—where he lives, wants to again escape his responsibility to tell the operators in this industry how this bill will apply to them in their day-to-day operations, how it will apply to their businesses, irrespective of where they operate those businesses around Australia. Here we are, prior to Christmas, looking at the relevant legislation and all has, surprisingly, not been revealed. There is no definition, for example, of what constitutes a journey. There is no indication of where the metropolitan or conurbation boundaries will begin and end. The bill, I suggest, flicks that unenviable task to the Commissioner of Taxation. Again, the government is walking away from its responsibilities because, apparently, it was all too hard for the minister for transport—as he has clearly displayed in question time on a number of occasions—and his department to answer those fundamental questions.

So, rather than seeking to work it out, what did the minister do? Again, he got on his bike and sought to run away from his responsibilities by handballing the issue to the Commissioner of Taxation. Under this bill, following consultation with industry representatives, the commissioner will supposedly determine in writing what will or will not constitute a journey for the purposes of the scheme. Five months after this deal with the Democrats was delivered, the government still has no idea how this scheme is going to work in practice. The government still cannot tell us whether those metropolitan boundaries will operate, how they will operate, for example, and how they will be drawn.

Earlier in this process, the opposition raised the possibility of satellite tracking as being the only reliable way of administering this scheme. Maybe that is what is happening here. Maybe they have a mate in the industry who wants to supply that service because, after all, they are not bad at looking after mates when it comes to handing out grants, as has clearly been displayed with respect to the federation grants. Maybe that is why there is no detail in this legislation. Maybe the minister has come to the same conclusion after five months of running around trying to devise some other mechanism. But he does not want to put that on the table. He does not want to be the National Party leader who introduces satellite spying on regional businesses.

What will the minister for transport now say if we ask him to tell us how the central element of this scheme, the notion of a journey, will be defined? He will say, `That's up to the Commissioner of Taxation. Don't ask me, I'm only the minister. I'm only the one who helped devise the scheme in consultation with the Democrats. I'm only the one who was part of a dirty little deal that conned the industry to get the Prime Minister's dirty little GST through the Senate. We didn't think about detail. We didn't think about what it would mean for operators in the industries—the mum and dad and the small and medium sized businesses—who would expect to actually try to make our mess operate. That wasn't for us to worry about. All we wanted to do was a dirty little deal with our mates the Democrats. You worry about that. You worry about the nightmare on highway 1 and all the administrative arrangements. That's your problem. That's your red tape. After all, we're just politicians. We don't worry about how it applies in industry. We'll again walk away from our responsibilities and allow industry to sort out the mess.'

I believe that, when we ask him where the metropolitan boundaries for Melbourne, for example, begin and end, he will say, `That's up to the Commissioner of Taxation. It's not my responsibility. It's not on my desk. It's nothing to do with me. The problem's solved.' Of course, it is not a problem solved for the Commissioner of Taxation and it is not a problem solved for all those rural and regional businesses which deliver into the cities and metropolitan areas and which are trying to work out just how this scheme will affect them.

What I most worry about when we have these complexities is not those hundreds of thousands of decent, honest operators who will seek to do the right thing by the Australian public and by the Commissioner of Taxation but all those people, including members of the front bench on the government side, who will seek to minimise their commitments and obligations to the Australian public through tax minimisation. Some of these operators will take the view that, if it is good enough for ministers of the Crown to minimise their tax through family trusts, it is good enough for them to try to minimise their responsibilities through the complexities and the nightmare created by the Diesel and Alternative Fuel Grants Scheme and the regulations and method of application which the Commissioner of Taxation will now be expected to put in place. So much for the member for Mitchell's claims this evening that no-one will seek to avoid their responsibilities under this scheme.

For those reasons, I think it is appropriate that those businesses know now what is ahead of them. They are going to have to keep substantial new records. They want to know what those records will be. They want that worked out now and they want it on the table for discussion in this House. But they also know that they are facing another layer of administration on top of the compliance burden associated with the GST—and this government says it is friendly to small business! This bill proves yet again that this government is far from friendly to any business in this country in the transport industry, be it small, large or medium sized.

They also know that the Commissioner of Taxation is being given extensive new powers to gather information in relation to the scheme. Those powers include stopping a vehicle, detaining a vehicle, asking for information about the destination of passengers or goods, searching a vehicle and taking fuel samples. Now it is official: the commissioner and the tax office are the new `dipstick police', in association with the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, `Dipstick' John Anderson. They all fit together in the mind of the minister for transport.

More importantly, we were told all this after the last election. I think the question ought to be answered about why the Australian public were not told about this before the last election. Not only were they not told about it; more importantly, they were not told the Commissioner of Taxation would be getting these new powers. They were not told that having your vehicle seized and detained and having fuel samples taken was going to be the price of this scheme.

Even leaving aside these intrusive new powers and lack of detail in the bill, the underlying problems with the scheme remain. There is still the inherent unfairness in trucks based in Goulburn, for example, getting the grant whilst those based in Gosford miss out, or trucks based in Seymour getting the grant whilst those based in Werribee do not. There is still the very real issue of the competitive balance between businesses changing overnight depending upon which side of a city they are located. There is still the issue of how—`dipstick police' or no `dipstick police'—you stop business just outside the metropolitan area making several delivery runs in and out of the city in order to qualify for the grant on each journey instead of making a one-off delivery round and only getting the grant for the first leg of that trip.

The Democrats still face the difficulty of explaining how and why they agreed to a scheme that continues to subsidise diesel fuel in the cities as long as the relevant journey starts outside a metropolitan area. All this particular bill does is reinforce two things: firstly, how the Democrats got done over in their deal with the government and, secondly, the complete failure of the minister for transport to deliver a workable and effective scheme arising out of that deal.

As I said earlier, it may not be possible to deliver a workable scheme without satellite tracking, but the government have repeatedly assured us that they could deliver such a scheme. They have rejected accusations that they pulled this scheme out of a hat in a desperate attempt to get the Democrats on board with the GST. I believe this bill gives the lie to those assertions. In his second reading speech, the minister says this bill will `enable industry to develop record keeping arrangements and plan with confidence for the introduction of the grants scheme on 1 July 2000'.

The opposition would like to know—and I presume, more importantly, the transport industry would like to know—on what basis we can all go forward with such confidence. It certainly cannot be based on the contents of the bill before the House for debate this evening.
